item.title: Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense
item.description:
%title%
True Value:
"Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense" By Anita Ramaswamy Jan 22, 2026
Intel‚Äôs stock price has more than doubled in the past five months, since President Donald Trump announced the U.S. government would buy a 10% stake in the ailing chip manufacturer, followed by similar investments from SoftBank and Nvidia. Investors are betting the new capital, coupled with a surge in AI demand, will help resuscitate the company.
Those expectations will collide with reality when Intel reports fourth-quarter earnings late this afternoon, either making or breaking the rally. Intel bears say the stock has moved way too high, setting it up for a big sell-off on Friday morning‚Äîparticularly if the company‚Äôs outlook for 2026 disappoints.
---

item.title: ‚òïü§ñ Apple‚Äôs AI Upgrade Could Be a Big Deal
item.description:
View this post on the web at https://theaibreak.substack.com/p/this-might-be-apples-biggest-ai-move
üöÄ Be featured in our next issue. üëâ work with us here [ https://substack.com/redirect/a95f4c40-7518-4958-a2a9-b9a82cf923d5?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] Hey fam üëã Luis & Rui here with your Thursday AI coffee break. This week, Apple‚Äôs Siri could be turning into a real chatbot, Claude‚Äôs ‚Äúnew constitution‚Äù just dropped, and YouTube is about to let creators generate Shorts using their own AI likeness. Grab your coffee! (3-minute coffee break‚òï) AI News around the world üåé üçè Apple is turning Siri into an AI bot that‚Äôs more like ChatGPT, as Apple races to modernize Siri with more advanced AI. (continue reading [ https://substack.com/redirect/3f1a1f18-066c-474c-892c-eba9c79add8d?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) üìú Anthropic released a new ‚Äúconstitution‚Äù describing Claude‚Äôs intended values and behavior and made it freely reusable under CC0. (continue reading [ https://substack.com/redirect/6e214509-78bf-4e00-8076-c03be4828dd4?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) üé¨ YouTube says creators will soon be able to generate Shorts using their own AI likeness, alongside other new AI creation tools and controls. (continue reading [ https://substack.com/redirect/5ee77193-f31e-414c-b99f-62fc3171aeb0?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) üéì OpenAI launches ‚ÄúEducation for Countries‚Äù to help governments and universities scale AI in education, including access to ChatGPT Edu and training/certifications. (continue reading [ https://substack.com/redirect/ad1b09d4-01fa-4791-8ffa-ee96a315563b?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) üö® Tutorial: Build Your Own AI Employees with Claude Skills [ https://substack.com/redirect/1519de54-53bb-49c7-ba12-5b438bb7160e?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] Tired of copy-pasting the same prompts into Claude every single day? This 15-minute guide shows you how to set up Claude Skills that remember exactly how you want work done. Inside: Tutorial + 5 ready-to-paste Skills (LinkedIn posts, status reports, meeting notes, cold emails, landing page copy). üëâ Read the Claude Skills Tutorial here [ https://substack.com/redirect/1519de54-53bb-49c7-ba12-5b438bb7160e?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] Trending AI Tools üõ† ‚úçÔ∏è HoppyCopy [ https://substack.com/redirect/b6cb8f79-66a4-4dbf-ad64-735c84783bfa?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]: AI copywriter built for email marketing: generate newsletters, sequences, subject lines, and ad copy fast. üß± 10Web [ https://substack.com/redirect/a291c31c-6a7f-485e-8997-a63f7bfcd890?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]: AI website builder for WordPress: generate a site from a prompt, then edit + optimize speed and performance. üí¨ Stirling [ https://substack.com/redirect/4652ecb7-a376-42ce-a738-b8aaeb607d12?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]: Create ads at scale by using your page url. ü§ñ MaybeTech [ https://substack.com/redirect/a44bbc7c-f26e-4137-8d14-8bf941f54a8c?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]: AI Agents that operate inside Slack or Teams, connect to the tools you already use, and take ownership of clearly defined workflows. (great for ops). Tutorials üìù Career & Capital üíº AI Job Board üß™ Anthropic: Finance AI Engineer - $205,000 to $265,000 (view job [ https://substack.com/redirect/ec7e2634-c080-4cb2-8c65-6130b7516085?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) ‚öñÔ∏è Norm AI: Software Engineer, Applied AI - $220,000 to $285,000 (view job [ https://substack.com/redirect/6bb77f67-b4ed-411e-a062-2048d770bc0a?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) üåç CVS Health: AI Machine Learning - $86,000 to $173,000 (view job [ https://substack.com/redirect/89a67b0e-6fe7-4dcb-bdb1-2b25bf2be210?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) Investments in AI ü§ñ OpenAI is reportedly seeking a $50B funding round (Middle East investors) (link [ https://substack.com/redirect/6961b079-2c4c-40ce-8968-fe3081442865?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) üí∞ UpScale AI: Raised $200M (Tiger Global) to build AI networking (link [ https://substack.com/redirect/2b373e8f-4b64-4a9a-88c6-e32e6d2fc7f4?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) üöÄ Breez AI: Raised $1.3M pre-seed (Wamda Capital-backed) (link [ https://substack.com/redirect/1644fdaf-6a14-479c-bdbd-b31d06288ea0?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]) Prompt of the Week üß† Customer Support ‚Üí Turn messy tickets into clear SOPs. If you manage support (or ops), this prompt helps you turn real customer issues into repeatable processes your team can follow. Prompt: You are an Operations Lead building internal SOPs from customer support tickets.
Your job: transform the ticket thread below into a clear, repeatable SOP that any new team member can follow.
Output format (exact): - SOP Title (max 8 words) - When to use this SOP (1 sentence) - Goal (1 sentence) - Required info to collect (bullet list) - Step-by-step process (numbered steps) - Decision tree (If/Then bullets for the 3 most common branches) - Copy-paste responses (3 templates: ‚Äúfirst reply‚Äù, ‚Äúneed more info‚Äù, ‚Äúresolved‚Äù) - Escalation rules (when to escalate + to who) - SOP owner + review cadence (suggest a role + how often to review)
Constraints: - Keep it practical, short sentences, no fluff - Assume the reader is new to the company - Highlight any missing info as ‚Äú‚ö†Ô∏è Missing‚Äù
Ticket thread (paste everything): [PASTE TICKET / EMAIL THREAD HERE]
Company context (optional): - Product: [what you sell] - Tools: [Zendesk/Intercom/Slack/etc. - Refund policy: [paste if relevant] Where to use it: Support teams, ops teams, founders handling support themselves, onboarding new reps, building a knowledge base fast. üö® Need help with AI? Here‚Äôs how we can help: ‚úÖ Become a PRO member ‚Üí Get exclusive AI tutorials, ready-to-use prompts, custom GPTs, and +50 automation workflows. Upgrade here [ https://substack.com/redirect/a39ac31a-a472-41c0-9a4b-53c13ea56833?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] ü§ñ Book an AI Audit ‚Üí We‚Äôll review your business and show you where AI can actually make an impact, cut unnecessary costs, and build workflows that work. Your AI growth partner. Book your AI Audit [ https://substack.com/redirect/578ba356-218d-4dee-80dc-61c83847641e?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] üì£ Sponsor Us ‚Üí Put your brand in front of 90,000+ founders and professionals. Work with us [ https://substack.com/redirect/1bfebb1b-b90e-48c7-b20a-0217de300a56?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] üôå That‚Äôs a wrap for today‚Äôs AI Break Thanks for hanging out ‚Üí don‚Äôt forget to hit subscribe, drop your thoughts below and share this update with your fellow AI enthusiasts. Luis & Rui PPS: If you enjoyed today‚Äôs AI Break, sharing is caring (and our algorithms are üòâ programmed for gratitude)

Source Code
[https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0IjoiV2hhdCB0aGUgVGVhbSBCZWhpbmQgQ3Vyc29yIEtub3dzIEFib3V0IHRoZSBGdXR1cmUgb2YgQ29kZSIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDcsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL2V2ZXJ5LnRvL3NvdXJjZS1jb2RlIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjF9]
WHAT THE TEAM BEHIND CURSOR KNOWS ABOUT THE FUTURE OF CODE [https://every.]
CURSOR TEAM MEMBERS SHARE THEIR THOUGHTS ON BUILDING SOFTWARE WITH AI AND WHY MODEL SELECTION BEATS PROMPTING TRICKS [https://every.]
by Katie Parrott [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0IjoiV2hhdCB0aGUgVGVhbSBCZWhpbmQgQ3Vyc29yIEtub3dzIEFib3V0IHRoZSBGdXR1cmUgb2YgQ29kZSIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDcsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL2V2ZXJ5LnRvL0BrYXRpZS5wYXJyb3R0MTIiLCJwb3NpdGlvbiI6NH0=]
[https://d24ovhgu8s7341.cloudfront.net/uploads/post/cover/3907/full_page_cover_What_the_Team_Behind_Cursor_Knows_About_the_Future_of_Code.png] Midjourney/Every illustration.
Happening now: We‚Äôre hosting Vibe Code Camp [https://every.] with the world‚Äôs best experts pushing the limits of what‚Äôs possible. Watch live now until 6 p.m. ET, and catch the recordings [https://every.]. Also: This article is based on a sponsored event. Cursor provided $100 in credits to attendees and made this camp possible.‚ÄîKate Lee [https://every.]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A few minutes into Every‚Äôs first Cursor Camp, Cursor developer education lead Lee Robinson [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0IjoiV2hhdCB0aGUgVGVhbSBCZWhpbmQgQ3Vyc29yIEtub3dzIEFib3V0IHRoZSBGdXR1cmUgb2YgQ29kZSIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDcsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL3guY29tL2xlZXJvYiIsInBvc2l0aW9uIjo4fQ==] made a bold declaration: ‚ÄúThe IDE is kind of dead.‚Äù
IIDE stands for ‚Äúintegrated development environment‚Äù‚Äîbasically Microsoft Word, but for code. It‚Äôs where programmers type, organize files, and run programs, and for decades, it has been the center of a programmer‚Äôs world.
Now, that model is breaking down. The center of gravity has shifted from typing code by hand in an IDE such as Visual Studio Code [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0IjoiV2hhdCB0aGUgVGVhbSBCZWhpbmQgQ3Vyc29yIEtub3dzIEFib3V0IHRoZSBGdXR1cmUgb2YgQ29kZSIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDcsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL2NvZGUudmlzdWFsc3R1ZGlvLmNvbS8iLCJwb3NpdGlvbiI6OX0=] to managing AI agents that write it for you with a tool such as Cursor.
In this session, Lee and Samantha Whitmore [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0IjoiV2hhdCB0aGUgVGVhbSBCZWhpbmQgQ3Vyc29yIEtub3dzIEFib3V0IHRoZSBGdXR1cmUgb2YgQ29kZSIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDcsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL3guY29tL3Nqd2hpdG1vcmUiLCJwb3NpdGlvbiI6MTB9], a software engineer at Cursor, walked us through how they work in a post-IDE world. What follows are the workflows, model-selection strategies, and honest limitations they shared‚Äîplus where this leaves you if you‚Äôre trying to figure out what the future of code looks like.
KEY TAKEAWAYS
1. The agent is becoming the core. Writing and editing code by hand is shrinking as a percentage of the work. Developers are now spending more time telling AI agents what to build and reviewing their output. 2. Cloud and local agents are merging. You‚Äôll soon be able to start an agent on your computer, hand it off to remote servers when you close your laptop, and pick it back up later‚Äîno context lost. 3. Model choice matters more than prompting tricks. Prompting gimmicks like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll pay you $1,000,‚Äù which some AI users swore could make AI provide a better output, don‚Äôt work anymore. You need to choose the right model for the job‚Äîsay, one for brainstorming, another for deep bug-hunting. 4. Agents can run for weeks. Cursor‚Äôs research team built a working web browser from scratch using AI agents that ran for days, producing 3 million lines of code. It cost $80,000 in tokens (the units AI companies use to measure and charge for usage). It‚Äôs a research project that‚Äôs not available for public use‚Äîfor now. But it shows where things are heading.
Uploaded image [https://d24ovhgu8s7341.cloudfront.net/uploads/editor/advertisements/933/optimized_efc62b49-a533-4a5a-a7e4-f45adbb5b9c5.png]https://every._dXRtX3NvdXJjZT1ldmVyeXRvXHUwMDI2dXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjExLCJhZHZlcnRpc2VtZW50X2lkIjo5MzN9
MOVE FAST, DON‚ÄôT BREAK THINGS
Most AI coding tools don‚Äôt know which line of code will actually break your system. Try Augment Code, which understands your entire codebase, including the repos, languages, and dependencies that actually runs your business, and use their playbook to learn more about their framework, checklists, and assessments. Ship 30% faster with 40% shorter merge times.
Playbook at augmentcode.com [https://every._dXRtX3NvdXJjZT1ldmVyeXRvXHUwMDI2dXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyXHUwMDI2c291cmNlPXBvc3RfYnV0dG9uIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjEyLCJhZHZlcnRpc2VtZW50X2lkIjo5MzN9] Want to sponsor Every? Click here [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0IjoiV2hhdCB0aGUgVGVhbSBCZWhpbmQgQ3Vyc29yIEtub3dzIEFib3V0IHRoZSBGdXR1cmUgb2YgQ29kZSIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDcsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJtYWlsdG86c3BvbnNvcnNoaXBzQGV2ZXJ5LnRvIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjEzfQ==].
WHAT ‚ÄòTHE DEATH OF THE IDE‚Äô MEANS
Cursor looks like a traditional coding tool on the surface. There are files on the left, code in the middle, and now an AI chat panel on the side, where you can ask the agent to do things.
What Cursor looks like when I open a project. (Image courtesy of Katie Parrott.) [https://d24ovhgu8s7341.cloudfront.net/uploads/editor/posts/3907/optimized_3f38c76f-d1a8-4fa4-bcaa-72e8761552ef.png]https://every. Cursor looks like when I open a project. (Image courtesy of Katie Parrott.)
For many Cursor users, that chat panel has become the main event. Some don‚Äôt even look at the code output much‚Äîthey work entirely in conversation with the AI, only reviewing the final result.
According to Lee, developers used to interact with Cursor primarily by writing code by hand and using an autocomplete function, where the AI suggests the next line of code as you type, similar to predictive text on your phone. But Lee says recent Cursor‚Äôs usage data tells a different story: More and more developers are working inside the agent interface. He said that writing code by hand may comprise as little as 10 percent of the time for some developers.
This is why he believes that easier text editing‚Äîfor which Cursor and tools like it were originally built‚Äîis less important than the coding agent‚Äîwhich writes and edits code‚Äîand the ability to review the agent‚Äôs output and track changes.
And with new tools and integrations being built every day (like Every‚Äôs compound engineering plugin [https://every.]), it seems likely the old ways of AI-enabled coding will slip farther down the ranking.
A BROWSER BUILT FROM SCRATCH BY AI (FOR $80,000)
When you use an AI coding tool, you‚Äôre really using two things: the model (the AI brain that generates code) and the scaffolding known as the harness around it (the infrastructure that lets that brain do things‚Äîrun commands, edit files, handle errors, and manage context). The model comes from OpenAI or Anthropic. The harness is what Cursor builds.
The same model can perform very differently depending on its harness. A well-tuned harness [https://every.] knows how to feed the model the right context, when to truncate long outputs, how to recover from errors, and how to keep the AI on track during long tasks.
To stress-test what a well-tuned harness could do, Cursor‚Äôs team built a custom research harness around GPT 5.2 [https://every.] and set it loose on an absurd task: building a fully functional web browser from scratch. AI produced 3 million lines of code across thousands of files, generated over weeks of continuous running, at a cost of around $80,000 in tokens. The browser that resulted could render web pages, handle Flexbox (a layout system for web design), display images, and run scripts.
At $80,000, this is a hefty research project, not something your average solo developer could try on a Tuesday afternoon. But a year ago, the same task would have been impossible at any price. If costs continue to come down, ‚ÄúLet the agent run for a week on something ambitious‚Äù might feel less like a stunt in time.
HOW A CURSOR CODER USES CURSOR
Cursor‚Äôs team uses Cursor to build Cursor. Their workflows are both a window into power-user techniques and a preview of where the tool is headed because the features they find themselves wanting tend to become the features they build.
Sam showed how she‚Äôs building features for Cursor‚Äôs cloud agents product, including the ability to move an agent from your local computer to the cloud‚Äîin other words, a remote server‚Äîand back.
Right now, if you start an AI agent on your laptop and then close it for lunch, the agent stops. Sam‚Äôs project would let you hand the agent off to run in the cloud, check on its progress from your phone, and have it back your computer when you‚Äôre ready.
PLANNING COMES FIRST
Before Sam writes any code, she spends serious time in ‚Äúplan mode,‚Äù a Cursor feature where you talk to the AI about what you want to build before it starts building. For complex projects, she‚Äôll share designs and screenshots, and have a long conversation to create a detailed plan.
The more detailed your upfront plan, the less the AI wanders off into expensive tangents. ‚ÄúPlan mode [https://every.]‚Äú‚Äîwhether in Cursor, Claude Code, or any other tool‚Äîhas become gospel among top AI-powered coders.
For large plans, Sam uses multiple agents working in parallel, manually breaking the work into pieces. For small-to-medium plans, she might use one or two agents. For simple bug fixes, she sometimes skips planning entirely.
MODEL SELECTION IS BASED ON VIBES
Sam has developed what she calls ‚Äúpersonal vibe assessments‚Äù for different AI models, rough heuristics for when to use which model:
1. Claude Opus [https://every.]: This is Sam‚Äôs brainstorming buddy. It‚Äôs good at connecting dots and helping when something is poorly specified, plus it can zoom out and correct itself. 2. GPT 5.2 Codex [https://every.] High: Sam says Codex has ‚Äúrobotic energy.‚Äù It takes you at your exact word. It‚Äôs also incredibly thorough for bug-finding, but it can get fixated on one approach instead of stepping back to try something different.
Sometimes she uses both at once, running the same task through multiple models in parallel and comparing the results. Cursor has a feature called ‚Äúbest of n‚Äù that lets you run up to eight models simultaneously on the same problem. Sometimes, if a bug is tricky to fix, Sam will have Codex and Opus go head-to-head to see which model‚Äôs approach comes out on top.
When multiple models return different answers, she interviews them. She‚Äôll ask one model to justify its approach, then share that reasoning with another model and ask what it thinks. It‚Äôs a bit manual, but it helps her understand the problem deeply before deciding what to do.
REVIEW IS PART OF THE WORKFLOW
Cursor has built-in review tools. There‚Äôs a ‚Äúfind issues‚Äù button that kicks off another agent to review the code from a fresh perspective. They also have a tool called Bugbot that automatically reviews GitHub [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0IjoiV2hhdCB0aGUgVGVhbSBCZWhpbmQgQ3Vyc29yIEtub3dzIEFib3V0IHRoZSBGdXR1cmUgb2YgQ29kZSIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDcsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL2dpdGh1Yi5jb20vIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjIxfQ==] pull requests (the drafts developers submit before code goes live) and flags likely bugs.
Sam said Cursor has an internal policy: Don‚Äôt merge code until you‚Äôve addressed all Bugbot comments.
RETRIEVAL OVER COMPRESSION
Sam has shifted her thinking in one more way recently. She used to think you needed to compress conversations into summaries for AI to remember past work. Now she prefers a ‚Äúretrieval first‚Äù approach: Instead of summaries, she gives the AI pointers to past conversations and plan documents and lets it explore them as needed.
‚ÄúThe agents have gotten so good at exploring pointers to files,‚Äù she said.
Q&A HIGHLIGHTS
Q: WHERE IS THE EARLY ACCESS CHANNEL FOR NEW FEATURES?
In Cursor settings under ‚Äúbeta,‚Äù you can choose between stable, early access, and nightly releases. Lee recommended early access for people who want to try new features without dealing with frequent bugs or crashes.
Q: HOW DOES CURSOR HANDLE CONTEXT AS AGENTS RUN LONGER?
Cursor now uses a ‚Äúpointer‚Äù system. Instead of stuffing the AI‚Äôs memory with full documents, it gives the agent pointers to files and lets it explore them as needed. This prevents the AI from getting confused by too much information at once.
‚ÄúThe models are smart enough now to go explore it and use file read tools and grep tools to explore this context as it needs,‚Äù Sam said. Grep refers to a command to search for and find matching text patterns in files.
Q: DO PROMPTING TRICKS LIKE ‚ÄúI‚ÄôLL PAY YOU $1,000‚Äù STILL WORK?
No. The Cursor team said steering the model with rewards or threats has become less important than managing context pollution (preventing the AI from being overwhelmed with irrelevant information). The models are already well-trained for coding tasks‚Äîthe trick is staying out of their way.
Q: I DO SIMPLE WEBSITES FROM FIGMA DESIGNS. I CAN‚ÄôT GET AGENTS TO MATCH THE DESIGN FASTER THAN DOING IT MYSELF.
Sam said this is tricky for companies like Cursor. The Figma integration is built by Figma, not the AI companies, so the models haven‚Äôt been trained on how to use it. You‚Äôll likely need to experiment more with your prompts to get good results.
For straightforward design-to-code translation‚Äîtaking a static design and turning it into working code, the bread and butter of many web developers‚ÄîAI tools still don‚Äôt reliably beat human speed. The gains seem concentrated in more complex, multi-step tasks where the AI can run longer and handle more scope.
QUESTIONS TO ASK BEFORE SWITCHING
As someone without a software engineering background but who vibe codes frequently, here‚Äôs what I came away from this camp thinking: Cursor‚Äôs vision is compelling‚Äîagents that run for weeks, seamlessly move between your laptop and the cloud, and handle projects that would take human developers months. But the gap between the demo and daily reality is worth examining.
A few things stood out:
The cost barrier is real‚Äîfor now. Sam admitted she ‚Äúliterally never looks at‚Äù token usage, relying on the $200-per-month unlimited plan. For people doing simpler tasks or with smaller budgets, the calculus might be different.
Design translation remains hard. The question about Figma-to-code workflows didn‚Äôt get a satisfying answer. If you‚Äôre a web developer doing straightforward implementation work, these tools may not save you time yet.
Model selection is becoming its own expertise. Knowing when to use Opus versus Codex, run multiple models in parallel, and interview the AI about its choices, among other things, is emerging as its own skill set.
That shift has implications beyond professional developers. If agents can build browsers from scratch, what else becomes possible for people who‚Äôve never written a line of code [https://every.]?
The answer, based on what I saw: complex, multi-step projects where you can describe what you want and review what you get. The simpler the task‚Äîthe more it‚Äôs about matching a specific design or writing a single function‚Äîthe less these tools help.
Whether the IDE is ‚Äúdead‚Äù or evolving, one thing is clear: The teams building these tools have huge amounts of influence on the direction AI-powered coding is headed. It‚Äôs good to know what they‚Äôre building‚Äîand to test their claims against your own experience.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

AI Frontiers on TechCrunch January 22, 2026 YouTube will soon let creators make Shorts with their own AI likeness ‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/youtube-will-soon-let-creators-make-shorts-with-their-own-ai-likeness/ ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/1cce9495-9db1-4c73-9119-92f65a37f63a.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/bcdd1c70-81fd-41f5-9747-0711e730802a.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ YouTube will enable creators to use AI-generated versions of their own likeness in Shorts, alongside tools for creating games and experimenting with music via text prompts. * ‚Ä¢ The platform is enhancing AI tools, such as AI stickers and auto-dubbing, while also providing creators with controls to manage and protect their likeness in AI-generated content. * ‚Ä¢ To combat low-quality AI content, YouTube is expanding its systems to reduce spam, clickbait, and repetitive content, ensuring a high-quality viewing experience.
----------------------------------------
Not to be outdone by OpenAI, Apple is reportedly developing an AI wearable ‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/not-to-be-outdone-by-openai-apple-is-reportedly-developing-an-ai-wearable/ ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/ea441acb-5f59-4ea7-ac06-64bc384fdeb8.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/656b32a2-8ed1-4530-9baa-330cc5c83e38.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ Apple is rumored to be working on an AI wearable pin featuring two cameras, three microphones, a speaker, and a physical button. The device is described as a sleek, aluminum-and-glass disc, slightly thicker than an AirTag. * ‚Ä¢ The pin, expected to launch by 2027 with 20 million units, aims to compete with OpenAI‚Äôs anticipated AI hardware, potentially a pair of earbuds, signaling growing competition in the AI hardware market. * ‚Ä¢ Similar devices, like Humane AI‚Äôs wearable pin, struggled to gain traction, raising questions about consumer demand for AI wearables.
----------------------------------------
Irony alert: Hallucinated citations found in papers from NeurIPS, the prestigious AI conference ‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/irony-alert-hallucinated-citations-found-in-papers-from-neurips-the-prestigious-ai-conference/ ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/cfd52c2a-3eec-4f6b-9154-4d2f352e03f2.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/89984048-f39f-4887-807f-f3b15d5eaab2.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ GPTZero analyzed 4,841 papers from the NeurIPS conference and identified 100 fake citations across 51 papers, highlighting how AI tools like LLMs can introduce errors even in high-stakes academic research. * ‚Ä¢ While the fake citations represent a small fraction of the total, their presence raises concerns about the integrity of scholarly publishing and the challenges of peer review under the pressure of massive submission volumes. * ‚Ä¢ The findings underscore a broader issue: if leading AI researchers struggle to verify AI-generated outputs, it raises questions about the reliability of AI usage in other fields.
----------------------------------------
Todoist‚Äôs app now lets you add tasks to your to-do list by speaking to its AI ‚Ä¢ Article: https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/21/todoists-app-now-lets-you-add-tasks-to-your-to-do-list-by-speaking-to-its-ai/ ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/4a6f04ac-25e4-4878-95bf-cedd39b2edc2.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/796e33cd-95c1-42a5-bcc8-0097c6f741a5.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ Todoist Ramble leverages AI and large language models to convert natural speech into organized tasks, capturing details like deadlines, priorities, and assignees in real time. * ‚Ä¢ Built on Google‚Äôs Gemini 2.5 Flash Live model via Vertex AI, the feature ensures secure processing with SOC2 Type II certification and does not store audio for AI training. * ‚Ä¢ Available in 38 languages across iOS, Android, desktop, and web, Ramble offers limited sessions for free users and unlimited access for Pro and Business plans, driving higher user upgrades during beta testing.
----------------------------------------

item.title: ü´≥üèº A crawling, detachable robot hand
item.description:
^**[Read Online](https://robotnews.therundown.ai/p/a-crawling-detachable-robot-hand?jwt_token=eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJzdWJzY3JpYmVyX2lkIjoiZTQyMjNjMTUtMTU3Ni00NmY2LTljMDAtZjA3YWVhMmY5YjgwIiwicHVibGljYXRpb25faWQiOiJkYzEzYmY1Ni1jZmI5LTRmMDgtYWY0NC0zMzFkZTY0OWU1MGIiLCJhY2Nlc3NfdHlwZSI6InJlYWQtb25seSIsImV4cCI6MTc2OTI2ODc1NywiaXNzIjoiaHR0cHM6Ly9hcHAuYmVlaGlpdi5jb20iLCJpYXQiOjE3NjkwOTU5NTd9.LmLu_nYhweIIwUYa85OH8ORJJjKtTcuFBW1l4cn-684)**^^ | ^^**[Sign Up](https://robotnews.therundown.ai/subscribe)**^^ | ^^**[Advertise](https://therundownai.typeform.com/to/kraZ1TSO)**^
---------- View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/8592a77e-c2e6-4d4f-9203-b511ebb98bc8/roboticsheader.png?t=1736700542) Follow image link: (https://rundown.ai/) Caption:
----------
---------- **Good morning, TT.** EPFL roboticists just built a robotic hand that can detach itself and crawl away from its arm ‚Äî basically ‚ÄúThing‚Äù from The Addams Family, but engineered in Switzerland.
With freakishly flexible, reversible fingers, it can grip from either side ‚Äî and even juggle extra tasks with a sixth digit. Is this the next big leap in real-world dexterity?
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
**In today‚Äôs robotics rundown:**
* Robotic hand detaches and crawls on its own
* Zipline soars to $7.6B as it targets Houston, Phoenix
* Sailbots take on Category 5 hurricanes
* Serve Robotics moves into hospital bots
* Quick hits on other robotics news
----------
---------- **LATEST DEVELOPMENTS**
----------
---------- ###### EPFL
#### ‚úåüèº _**[Robotic hand detaches and crawls on its own](https://news.epfl.ch/news/reversible-detachable-robotic-hand-redefines-dex-2/)**_
View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/e4a6abb0-d308-4282-bc4c-a0c5581129c8/1108x622.jpg?t=1769075974) Caption: Image source: EPFL
**The Rundown: **Researchers at Switzerland‚Äôs EPFL just [built](https://news.epfl.ch/news/reversible-detachable-robotic-hand-redefines-dex-2/) a robotic hand that can detach from its arm, scuttle across a surface, and grab objects beyond the reach of conventional manipulators_._
**The details: **
* The EPFL team built this robotic hand from 3D printable parts, with the ability to detach from its arm, crawl, grab objects, and reattach itself.
* The reversible design lets any finger combination form opposing thumb-like pairs, enabling grasping from either side without repositioning.
* Each finger bends in both directions with more than twice the range of motion of a human hand, optimized via genetic algorithms for grasping and locomotion.
* With five fingers, it replicates most human grasps; add a sixth finger, and it can tackle two-handed tasks singlehandedly, like unscrewing a large bottle cap.
**Why it matters: **This hand challenges a core assumption in robotics ‚Äî that manipulators must stay bolted to their arms. By treating it as an autonomous agent that can deploy, complete a task, and return, EPFL‚Äôs design hints at a future where robotic limbs become interchangeable tools rather than fixed appendages.
----------
---------- ###### ZIPLINE
#### üåØ[ ](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2026/01/21/3222432/0/en/Zipline-Surpasses-2-Million-Deliveries-Raises-More-than-600M-to-Power-Next-Phase-of-Growth-and-Expands-Operations-to-Houston-and-Phoenix.html)[_**Zipline soars to $7.6B as it targets Houston, Phoenix**_](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2026/01/21/3222432/0/en/Zipline-Surpasses-2-Million-Deliveries-Raises-More-than-600M-to-Power-Next-Phase-of-Growth-and-Expands-Operations-to-Houston-and-Phoenix.html)
View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/0eaf44b6-f325-421a-ad34-54f27c4d7ec3/zipline-drone-delivery-2-million-houston-phoenix_cropped_processed_by_imagy.jpeg?t=1769071315) Caption: Image source: Zipline
**The Rundown: **Zipline just [raised](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2026/01/21/3222432/0/en/Zipline-Surpasses-2-Million-Deliveries-Raises-More-than-600M-to-Power-Next-Phase-of-Growth-and-Expands-Operations-to-Houston-and-Phoenix.html) more than $600M to fuel a fresh U.S. push that will launch its autonomous drone delivery in Houston and Phoenix in early 2026 and support expansion into at least four states.
**The details:**
* Zipline‚Äôs valuation has nearly tripled in under three years, leaping from $2.75B in mid-2021 to $7.6B today.
* Zipline says it has surpassed 2M commercial deliveries globally, with its drones flying more than 125M autonomous miles and delivering over 20M items.
* The company began operations in 2016, delivering blood by drone in Rwanda, and has spent the past decade building a vertically integrated logistics stack.
* Its Platform 2 drones, tailored for suburban home delivery, can carry up to 8 lb. within a 10‚Äëmile radius, while the Platform 1 handles 120‚Äëmile round trips.
**Why it matters: **Zipline says its newest U.S. sites can ramp to 100 deliveries a day in just two days, turning what used to be slow, geofenced pilots into something that starts to look like real infrastructure. Rivals Amazon Prime Air and Walmart‚Äôs drone partners Wing and DroneUp are [pushing](https://robotnews.therundown.ai/p/walmart-expands-drone-empire) hard too ‚Äî the drone wars are officially on.
----------
---------- ###### CLIMATE ROBOTICS
#### üåä [_**Sailbots take on Category 5 hurricanes**_](https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/17/oshen-built-the-first-ocean-robot-to-collect-data-in-a-category-5-hurricane/)
View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/b1b4eaf4-8560-426a-bdf2-836913b48a8a/Oshen_cropped_processed_by_imagy.jpeg?t=1769007292) Caption: Image source: Oshen
**The Rundown: **Bootstrapped UK startup Oshen has built swarms of low-cost autonomous ‚ÄúC-Star‚Äù robots that recently became the first ocean bots to survive and collect data from inside a Category 5 hurricane, its founder [told](https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/17/oshen-built-the-first-ocean-robot-to-collect-data-in-a-category-5-hurricane/) Techcrunch.
**The details:**
* Oshen builds autonomous micro-robots that can survive up to 100 days at sea and are cheap enough to deploy in swarms for ocean data collection.
* Founder Anahita Laverack launched the company in 2022 after realizing how little real-time ocean data exists for weather and climate modeling.
* OAA commissioned Oshen to deploy C-Stars near the U.S. Virgin Islands for Hurricane Humberto; three of five bots rode out the full Category 5 storm.
* Oshen, now based in Plymouth (England‚Äôs marine tech hub), is signing new government and defense contracts, including with the UK government.
**Why it matters:** Oshen‚Äôs C-Star swarms show how micro-robots could plug a critical gap in hurricane and climate models by streaming real-time data from places that are tough to reach, intensifying competition with larger uncrewed fleets like Saildrone‚Äôs USVs already collecting high-res storm data for NOAA and navies worldwide.
----------
---------- ###### SERVE ROBOTICS
#### üè• _**[Serve Robotics moves into hospital bots](https://investors.serverobotics.com/news-releases/news-release-details/serve-robotics-acquire-diligent-robotics-expanding-physical-ai)**_
View image: (https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/e7c5aad8-e099-41ce-a9b8-8cc968eae38f/serve-diligent_cropped_processed_by_imagy.jpeg?t=1769010298) Caption: Image source: Serve Robotics
**The Rundown: **Serve Robotics is pushing beyond burrito runs into the far messier world of hospital logistics, [agreeing](https://investors.serverobotics.com/news-releases/news-release-details/serve-robotics-acquire-diligent-robotics-expanding-physical-ai) to buy Austin-based Diligent Robotics in an all-stock deal valuing the startup at about $29M.
**The details:**
* The deal extends Serve from sidewalk delivery to hospital logistics, but CEO Ali Kashani frames it as a natural expansion of the same autonomy stack.
* Diligent‚Äôs Moxi robots are already one of the largest deployed hospital service fleets in the U.S., with roughly 100 robots across more than 25 hospitals.
* Serve plans to keep Diligent operating independently while sharing software, autonomy tools, and data so that ‚Äúevery robot learns from every robot.‚Äù
* Serve‚Äôs sidewalk fleet, which runs on both DoorDash and Uber Eats networks, scaled from 100 to more than 2K robots over the past year.
**Why it matters: **This deal turns Serve from a niche food-delivery player into one of the first companies running a shared autonomy stack across both public sidewalks and hospital corridors ‚Äî a real-world stress test for ‚Äúphysical AI,‚Äù the bet that one platform can learn to navigate any human-occupied space and port those lessons everywhere.
----------
---------- **QUICK HITS**
----------
---------- ### üì∞ **_[Everything else in robotics today](https://robotnews.therundown.ai/)_**
**1X‚Äôs VP of AI, Eric Jang,** who helped scale 1X from a small Norway-based startup to a global humanoid giant, [announced](https://x.com/ericjang11/status/2014049730448466327) on X that he is leaving the company.
**Chinese robotics firm UBTech** [signed](https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/ubtech-agrees-airbus-deal-expand-robot-use-aviation-manufacturing-2026-01-21/) a deal to supply its Walker S2 humanoids to Airbus for aviation manufacturing, which sent UBTech‚Äôs shares surging.
**UBTech **[says](https://interestingengineering.com/ai-robotics/video-humanoid-robots-automation-wind-turbine-plant) its Walker S2 humanoids are now autonomously performing assembly and material-handling tasks inside a Chinese wind turbine factory.
**XPeng‚Äôs CEO, He Xiaopeng,** [said](https://interestingengineering.com/ai-robotics/xpeng-et1-humanoid-prototype-production) their automotive-grade ET1 humanoid has rolled off the production line, with the first mass-produced test units focused on reliability.
**Hyundai‚Äôs Boston Dynamics** [hired](https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/other/hyundai-taps-former-tesla-robotics-leader-for-advisory-role-at-boston-dynamics/ss-AA1UAfy6) Milan Kovac, Tesla‚Äôs former senior VP and head of the Optimus humanoid program, as a group adviser and outside director.
**DEEP Robotics** [launched](https://www.accessnewswire.com/newsroom/en/industrial-and-manufacturing/deep-robotics-unveils-new-emergency-firefighting-robot-dog-solution-re-1128900) an AI-powered firefighting system that uses coordinated robot dogs and other specialized robots to handle high-risk firefighting missions.
**Microsoft** [unveiled](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/story/advancing-ai-for-the-physical-world/) Rho-alpha, a robotics AI that converts everyday language into robot actions by combining vision and touch for more reliable real-world manipulation.
**Boston Dynamics **[updated](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=de06_CLqrM0) its Spot platform and Orbit software to version 5.1 and introduced the Spot Cam 2 sensor head, sharpening its inspection capabilities.
**Zhejiang University** researchers [built](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-67148-y) FlexiRay, a soft robotic gripper that uses an internal camera and mirror system to ‚Äúsee‚Äù around corners.
----------
---------- **COMMUNITY**
----------
---------- ### **üéì **_**[Highlights: News, Guides & Events](https://app.therundown.ai/)**_
* Read our last AI newsletter: [Anthropic writes Claude's Constitution](https://www.therundown.ai/p/anthropic-writes-claudes-constitution)
* Read our last Tech newsletter: [Biotech‚Äôs big three (and they‚Äôre wild)](https://www.rundown.ai/articles/biotechs-big-3-and-they-re-wild)
* Read our last Robotics newsletter: [1X now has a world model](https://www.rundown.ai/articles/1x-now-has-a-world-model)
* Today‚Äôs AI tool guide: [Make Claude an expert at anything with Skills repo](https://app.therundown.ai/guides/make-claude-an-expert-at-anything-with-this-skills-repo)
* RSVP to next workshop @ 4PM EST Thursday: [AI Foundations Bootcamp pt.3](https://app.therundown.ai/calendar-events/695aad31c08489e266340b78)
----------
---------- See you soon,
_Rowan, Joey, Zach, Shubham, and Jennifer ‚Äî The Rundown‚Äôs editorial team_
---------- ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News January 22, 2026 Your brain on ChatGPT: Accumulation of cognitive debt when using an AI assistant ‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46712678 ‚Ä¢ Score: 383 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/af3ec161-f09a-40ad-8f3b-796c1879ce8b.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/e5cc4eb7-1ff8-4845-add9-eb94acf1ed86.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ A study compared essay writing across three groups: AI-powered Large Language Models (LLMs), Search Engine users, and Brain-only (no tools). Results showed LLM users had the weakest brain connectivity and lowest cognitive engagement, while Brain-only participants demonstrated the strongest neural activity. * ‚Ä¢ LLM reliance led to reduced cognitive ownership and long-term underperformance in neural, linguistic, and behavioral metrics. Participants transitioning from LLMs to Brain-only writing struggled with cognitive engagement, raising concerns about AI's educational impact. * ‚Ä¢ Findings highlight the trade-offs between immediate convenience offered by LLMs and potential cognitive costs, emphasizing the need for further research into AI's role in learning.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Themes and Topics**: * ‚Ä¢ **Cognitive Impact of AI Usage**: Many commenters discussed how relying on AI, particularly for tasks like coding or essay writing, can lead to cognitive atrophy, reduced engagement, and diminished understanding of the underlying material. However, others noted that AI can be a valuable tool when used correctly, such as for explaining concepts or accelerating productivity. * ‚Ä¢ **Historical Comparisons**: A recurring theme was comparing AI to past technological advancements (e.g., writing, calculators, GPS). Commenters debated whether these tools fundamentally shifted or diminished human cognitive abilities and whether similar concerns about AI are justified. * ‚Ä¢ **AI as a Tool vs. Replacement**: Several commenters highlighted the distinction between using AI as an assistive tool versus allowing it to take over tasks entirely. Many advocated for using AI to augment human work rather than replace critical thinking or hands-on learning. * ‚Ä¢ **Educational and Long-Term Implications**: Concerns were raised about how reliance on AI might affect learning, skill development, and problem-solving over time. Commenters discussed the potential for AI to disrupt traditional education and training pipelines, particularly in fields like programming. * ‚Ä¢ **Personal Experiences with AI**: Commenters shared anecdotes about their own experiences with AI tools, ranging from increased productivity and overcoming ADHD-related challenges to feeling disengaged or frustrated when relying too heavily on AI. * * 2. **Agreements and Disagreements**: * ‚Ä¢ **Agreements**: * ‚Ä¢ Many agreed that over-reliance on AI can lead to skill atrophy and reduced cognitive engagement. * ‚Ä¢ There was broad consensus that AI tools are most effective when used as aids for learning or productivity rather than as replacements for human effort. * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters supported the idea that AI should be used to focus on higher-level tasks while offloading repetitive or tedious work. * ‚Ä¢ **Disagreements**: * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters believed that AI is fundamentally different from past tools like calculators or writing because it can take over entire cognitive processes, while others argued that such concerns mirror historical fears about new technologies. * ‚Ä¢ There was debate about whether the downsides of AI use outweigh its benefits, with some emphasizing the risks of cognitive decline and others highlighting its potential for augmenting human capabilities. * ‚Ä¢ A few commenters dismissed the study as flawed or unscientific, while others found its findings credible and aligned with their own observations. * * 3. **Unique Insights and Notable Contributions**: * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters noted the importance of actively engaging with AI tools (e.g., asking questions, fact-checking) to mitigate cognitive atrophy and enhance learning. * ‚Ä¢ A comparison was made between managing AI and managing human subordinates, suggesting that principles of good management could inform effective AI use. * ‚Ä¢ Some highlighted the potential for AI to create a divide between those who rely heavily on it and those who retain traditional problem-solving skills, potentially leading to a "talent crunch" in certain fields. * ‚Ä¢ A few commenters proposed solutions to mitigate AI's negative effects, such as using it to create personalized learning experiences or imposing limits on its accessibility. * * 4. **Overall Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The discussion was mixed, with a balance of cautious optimism and concern. While many commenters acknowledged the productivity and learning benefits of AI, there was significant apprehension about its long-term cognitive and societal impacts. The tone ranged from reflective and analytical to skeptical and critical, with occasional humor and sarcasm. * * 5. **Key Takeaways**: * ‚Ä¢ AI tools can enhance productivity and learning but require careful, intentional use to avoid negative cognitive effects. * ‚Ä¢ Historical parallels suggest that concerns about AI may be part of a broader pattern of initial resistance to new technologies, though AI's unique capabilities raise distinct challenges. * ‚Ä¢ The long-term implications of AI reliance on education, skill development, and societal structures remain uncertain and warrant further research and consideration.
----------------------------------------
How AI destroys institutions ‚Ä¢ Article: https://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/publications/how-ai-destroys-institutions/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46705606 ‚Ä¢ Score: 298 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/261c4623-d1a8-45ed-9e5a-65da6903df7d.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/350482aa-92a1-459f-98bb-801ddd41f017.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ Civic institutions like the rule of law, universities, and a free press rely on transparency, cooperation, and accountability to adapt and sustain democratic life, empowering individuals to challenge norms and foster stability. * ‚Ä¢ Current AI systems undermine these foundational principles by eroding expertise, disrupting decision-making processes, and isolating individuals, making them incompatible with the evolution and legitimacy of civic institutions. * ‚Ä¢ The essay argues that AI‚Äôs design and functionality pose a severe threat to the survival of vital democratic structures, calling for urgent recognition of this existential risk.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Themes and Topics**: * ‚Ä¢ The role of AI in accelerating societal changes and its impact on institutions like universities, the press, and the rule of law. * ‚Ä¢ The debate over whether AI is the root cause of institutional decline or merely an accelerant of pre-existing issues. * ‚Ä¢ Concerns about AI eroding expertise, critical thinking, and interpersonal connections. * ‚Ä¢ Broader societal factors contributing to the erosion of trust in institutions, such as capitalism, corruption, and social media. * ‚Ä¢ The potential for AI to democratize access to knowledge and tools, but also the risks of misinformation and accountability gaps. * * 2. **Key Points of Agreement**: * ‚Ä¢ Many commenters agree that AI is amplifying existing problems rather than creating them from scratch. * ‚Ä¢ There is consensus that institutions were already facing challenges, such as declining trust, inefficiency, and corruption, before the rise of AI. * ‚Ä¢ AI‚Äôs ability to enhance productivity and accessibility is acknowledged, but it comes with the caveat of needing careful management. * * 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**: * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters argue that AI should be blamed for accelerating institutional decline, likening it to "throwing gas on a fire," while others believe the root causes lie elsewhere, such as in capitalism or systemic failures. * ‚Ä¢ Diverging views on whether AI is fundamentally destructive or can be harnessed positively to complement institutions. * ‚Ä¢ Opinions differ on whether institutions like universities and the press are still essential or have become outdated and self-serving. * * 4. **Unique Insights**: * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters highlight that institutional fragility predates AI and is tied to broader societal trends, such as the commodification of education and the influence of profit-driven motives. * ‚Ä¢ A commenter draws parallels between AI and previous technological disruptions, such as the internet and YouTube, which restructured traditional industries without completely destroying them. * ‚Ä¢ Another perspective emphasizes the potential for AI to exacerbate societal inequalities by empowering those who can use it effectively while disadvantaging others. * * 5. **Sentiment of the Discussion**: * ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment is mixed, with a blend of skepticism, concern, and cautious optimism. * ‚Ä¢ Many commenters express frustration with existing institutions and their inability to adapt, but there is also apprehension about AI‚Äôs potential to destabilize society further. * ‚Ä¢ Some comments reflect a sense of inevitability about AI-driven changes, while others call for proactive regulation and accountability. * * 6. **Notable Contributions**: * ‚Ä¢ The analogy of AI as a "wrecking ball" or "accelerant" was frequently used to describe its impact on fragile systems. * ‚Ä¢ Commenters debated the role of institutional trust, with some arguing that institutions must earn trust by improving lives, while others believe trust has eroded due to systemic corruption. * ‚Ä¢ The discussion touched on the dual nature of AI: as a tool for empowerment and democratization, but also as a potential source of harm if misused. * * 7. **Concluding Observations**: * ‚Ä¢ The discussion reflects deep concerns about the interplay between AI and societal structures, with no clear consensus on how to address the challenges. * ‚Ä¢ While some commenters see AI as a tool for progress, others view it as a threat to the foundational principles of democratic life. * ‚Ä¢ The debate underscores the need for thoughtful regulation, transparency, and public accountability in the deployment of AI technologies.
----------------------------------------
eBay explicitly bans AI "buy for me" agents in user agreement update ‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.valueaddedresource.net/ebay-bans-ai-agents-updates-arbitration-user-agreement-feb-2026/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46711574 ‚Ä¢ Score: 209 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/766ad7d6-82a4-4ce2-9cc8-1c4fd24ba56d.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/6c2e5356-b457-4986-8a7e-bab0853ec139.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ eBay explicitly prohibits AI-driven "buy for me" agents and large language model (LLM) bots from interacting with its platform without prior permission, aiming to prevent unauthorized automated transactions and data scraping. * ‚Ä¢ Arbitration updates include clarified class action waivers, an opt-out process, and a revised physical address for dispute notices, enhancing transparency in dispute resolution. * ‚Ä¢ The move aligns with broader industry concerns, potentially responding to Amazon's controversial AI-powered commerce experiments, highlighting growing scrutiny around AI's role in e-commerce.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Theme**: The discussion centers on eBay's ban on AI-powered "buy-for-me" bots, with participants debating the rationale, implications, and fairness of the decision. * * 2. **Key Points of Discussion**: * ‚Ä¢ **eBay's Motivation**: * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters argue that the ban is primarily about protecting eBay's business model, particularly its reliance on impulse buying, ad revenue, and user engagement ("wandering attention"). * ‚Ä¢ Others suggest the ban is aimed at avoiding potential liabilities, such as AI errors leading to incorrect purchases, returns, or scams. * ‚Ä¢ Some see it as a move to prevent AI from commoditizing eBay into a backend database, reducing its role in the user experience. * ‚Ä¢ **Fairness and Double Standards**: * ‚Ä¢ Many express frustration that eBay allows sniping bots (which bid at the last moment in auctions) but bans "buy-for-me" bots, viewing this as inconsistent. * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters note that sniping bots benefit eBay by keeping users engaged on the platform, whereas "buy-for-me" bots bypass user interaction and reduce ad exposure. * ‚Ä¢ **User Experience and AI Utility**: * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters highlight the potential usefulness of AI agents for tasks like monitoring listings, identifying deals, and automating purchases, particularly for niche or time-sensitive needs. * ‚Ä¢ Concerns are raised about the challenges of teaching AI to accurately interpret user preferences and avoid errors. * ‚Ä¢ Some suggest that eBay's poor user experience, including excessive notifications and spam, pushes users toward automating their interactions via AI. * ‚Ä¢ **Scalability and Abuse**: * ‚Ä¢ Participants discuss the potential for AI-driven automation to be abused at scale, such as by drop shippers or arbitrageurs who scrape listings and relist them for profit, creating additional load on platforms. * ‚Ä¢ Commenters also note that such automation could lead to increased returns, cancellations, and fraud, further straining eBay's infrastructure. * ‚Ä¢ **Enforcement Challenges**: * ‚Ä¢ Many are skeptical about eBay's ability to enforce the ban, given the sophistication of bots and the difficulty of distinguishing them from human users. * ‚Ä¢ Others argue that the ban is more about creating a policy framework to address issues as they arise rather than immediate, proactive enforcement. * * 3. **Unique Insights**: * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters suggest that eBay could monetize AI interactions by licensing API access or offering official AI tools, similar to how other companies are adapting to AI's impact. * ‚Ä¢ There is a broader reflection on how AI could disrupt marketplaces by leveling the playing field against existing automation (e.g., sniping bots, scalpers). * * 4. **Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment is mixed, with significant skepticism toward eBay's motives and policies. While some acknowledge the potential risks of AI automation, many view the ban as self-serving and indicative of broader issues with eBay's business practices and user experience. * * 5. **Notable Contributions**: * ‚Ä¢ A few commenters highlight practical use cases for AI in e-commerce, such as assisting blind users or automating complex purchase decisions. * ‚Ä¢ Others share personal experiences with eBay, illustrating frustrations with fees, fraud, and the platform's declining usability. * * 6. **Broader Implications**: * ‚Ä¢ The discussion reflects a larger tension between the benefits of AI-driven automation for users and the challenges it poses for businesses reliant on traditional engagement models. * ‚Ä¢ Commenters note parallels with other industries adapting to AI, suggesting that eBay's move is part of a broader trend of companies seeking to protect their revenue streams in the face of technological disruption.
----------------------------------------
Letting Claude play text adventures ‚Ä¢ Article: https://borretti.me/article/letting-claude-play-text-adventures ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46652173 ‚Ä¢ Score: 141 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/5943cd85-4ea1-4d7a-84a1-73ad0d45504a.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/322805d3-a80e-4b08-80ec-06e43ea93ff0.mp3

ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ An AI hackathon participant experimented with combining cognitive architecture principles, like those from Soar and ACT-R, with large language models (LLMs) to improve their performance in long-horizon tasks, using text adventure games as a testing ground. * ‚Ä¢ The project highlighted challenges such as token limitations and memory management in LLMs, leading to the development of experimental harnesses, including semantic memory and task-specific tools, to enhance efficiency and gameplay navigation. * ‚Ä¢ Future plans include implementing domain-specific memories, automatic and manual geography mapping, and episodic memory to refine LLMs' ability to handle complex, structured environments more effectively.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion revolves around using large language models (LLMs), particularly Claude, to play text adventure games, with a focus on memory management, reasoning capabilities, and experimental frameworks. * * 2. **Themes**: * ‚Ä¢ **Training Data and Performance**: Several commenters speculate on whether Claude's training data includes walkthroughs or transcripts of games like Anchorhead. Opinions vary on whether this would impact its ability to solve puzzles effectively. * ‚Ä¢ **Memory and Context Management**: There is significant discussion on how LLMs handle memory, with suggestions for structured memory tools, periodic summaries, and context compaction to improve performance in long-running sessions. * ‚Ä¢ **Symbolic AI and Hybrid Approaches**: Some commenters debate the relevance of symbolic AI in modern systems, suggesting it could serve as scaffolding for LLMs to handle causality and constraints better. * ‚Ä¢ **Applications and Experiments**: Commenters share their experiments, such as using Claude to play MUDs, Z-Machine games, and Dwarf Fortress clones, highlighting its potential for testing interactive fiction and software development. * ‚Ä¢ **Challenges with LLMs**: Observations include inefficiencies in maze-solving, high token costs for long sessions, and the inability of LLMs to manage their own memory optimally. * * 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**: * ‚Ä¢ There is general agreement that LLMs struggle with memory management and could benefit from external tools or structured frameworks. * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters are skeptical about the performance of LLMs in solving puzzles or playing games, especially if the games are well-known and potentially included in training data. * ‚Ä¢ Others highlight promising use cases for LLMs, such as testing game development or enhancing text adventure experiences. * * 4. **Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The sentiment is mixed. Many commenters express enthusiasm for the potential of LLMs in gaming and testing applications, while others are critical of their current limitations, such as inefficiencies and lack of contextual awareness. * * 5. **Unique Insights**: * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters propose innovative approaches to improve LLM performance, such as combining structured memory tools with symbolic AI, externalizing geometry in mazes, and using file-based memory types to mimic human-like recall. * ‚Ä¢ The idea of using LLMs for CI/CD testing in interactive fiction development is highlighted as a novel application. * ‚Ä¢ The concept of treating memory as structured game objects with explicit states and affordances is proposed as a way to enhance reasoning and coherence. * * 6. **Overall Summary**: * ‚Ä¢ The discussion showcases both the potential and limitations of LLMs in playing text adventure games. While there is excitement about experimental frameworks and applications, commenters emphasize the need for better memory management and structured approaches to improve reasoning and gameplay capabilities. Hybrid approaches combining symbolic AI and LLMs are suggested as a promising direction for addressing current challenges.
----------------------------------------
Comic-Con Bans AI Art After Artist Pushback ‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.404media.co/comic-con-bans-ai-art-after-artist-pushback/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46705952 ‚Ä¢ Score: 124 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/7f3c8a7b-4332-4450-89e9-c2ae4fa9bbbb.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/c12f2e1a-f43e-4c31-ae70-95c1215cfcd5.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ San Diego Comic-Con reversed its AI-friendly policy for its art show after an artist-led protest, now banning all AI-generated content to protect the integrity of creative work. * ‚Ä¢ Artists like Karla Ortiz highlighted how generative AI undermines livelihoods by replacing traditional creative processes, with examples from Marvel and Coca-Cola showcasing the growing industry reliance on AI. * ‚Ä¢ Despite the policy change, concerns persist as AI-generated art continues to appear at conventions, raising ethical debates about its exploitation of original artworks without credit or compensation.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Themes and Topics**: * ‚Ä¢ The ethics and legitimacy of AI-generated art, particularly in creative spaces like conventions. * ‚Ä¢ The evolving definition of art and the boundaries between traditional, digital, and AI-assisted creation. * ‚Ä¢ Concerns about authenticity, craftsmanship, and the impact of AI on artistic livelihoods. * ‚Ä¢ The role of tools and technology in the creative process, including comparisons to past innovations like Photoshop and photography. * * 2. **Key Points of Discussion**: * ‚Ä¢ Many commenters argue that AI-generated art lacks the moral and creative authenticity valued by traditional artists, especially when training data involves unconsented use of existing works. * ‚Ä¢ There is disagreement over whether AI tools are simply another medium for creativity or if they undermine the artistic process by removing human skill and effort. * ‚Ä¢ Some contributors highlight historical parallels, such as debates around digital art and the use of assistants in traditional art, suggesting that resistance to new technologies is not new. * ‚Ä¢ Others propose a spectrum of AI involvement in art, ranging from minor assistance to fully AI-generated works, with the degree of human engagement influencing perceptions of value and authenticity. * ‚Ä¢ Concerns about false accusations of AI use and the potential for AI-generated content to dominate spaces like conventions were also raised. * * 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**: * ‚Ä¢ There is broad agreement that generative AI raises ethical concerns, particularly around copyright and training data. However, views differ on whether AI art can or should be considered "real art. * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters believe AI tools could be valuable for enhancing creativity or automating repetitive tasks, while others feel they fundamentally devalue artistic work. * ‚Ä¢ Disagreement exists over whether AI art will eventually be accepted as part of the artistic landscape, with some predicting it will follow the trajectory of past technological shifts and others expressing skepticism about its long-term viability in creative fields. * * 4. **Overall Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The sentiment is mixed but leans toward skepticism and concern about the implications of AI art on creativity, ethics, and artistic livelihoods. While some commenters are optimistic about AI's potential as a tool, many express fears about its impact on authenticity and the art community. * * 5. **Unique Insights and Contributions**: * ‚Ä¢ Comparisons to Andy Warhol's factory and historical shifts in art (e.g., photography) suggest that art has always balanced ideas and skill, and AI might represent another stage in this evolution. * ‚Ä¢ The notion of AI art as a form of "false scarcity" or simulacrum highlights deeper philosophical concerns about the nature of creativity and substance in art. * ‚Ä¢ Practical observations, such as AI scrapers impacting artists' websites and conventions banning AI art, underscore real-world tensions between traditional and AI-assisted art. * * 6. **Conclusion**: * ‚Ä¢ The discussion reflects an ongoing debate about the place of AI in the creative world, with strong opinions on both sides. While some see AI as a tool that can complement human creativity, others worry it undermines the essence of art and the livelihoods of artists. The conversation highlights ethical, philosophical, and practical challenges that will likely continue as AI technologies evolve.
----------------------------------------

item.title: State of Markets
item.description:
View this post on the web at https://www.a16z.news/p/state-of-markets
We‚Äôre pleased to share our inaugural ‚ÄúState of Markets‚Äù slide deck. We share what we‚Äôre seeing in the private and public markets, what the state of AI looks like to us, and why today‚Äôs winners are just built different. You can read the deck here [ https://substack.com/redirect/3e7108f1-7eed-4350-8a52-b7634d5c8242?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] (it takes a second to load, there‚Äôs a lot in there): Here‚Äôs a sample of what‚Äôs in there: Unicorns are real‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs a power law business; always has been. In 2025, Revenue growth exploded upwards for the top quartile and top decile companies, far more than for everybody else. And they run in herds. As private unicorns broke through the $5T mark in aggregate, it‚Äôs clear who‚Äôs driving the trend: the biggest names. Subscribe for more from a16z every weekday: Meanwhile, in the public markets, a similar story is playing out: Higher the earnings, higher the multiple Winners keep winning, whether we‚Äôre talking sectors or individual winners. This isn‚Äôt a ‚Äú1x EV TAM‚Äù kind of market: the biggest multiples are getting assigned to the big earnings day winners. Tech is its own supercycle Zooming out, those winners tend to be tech companies, and those tech companies have pulled far away from everybody else. Tech isn‚Äôt just a subset of companies; it‚Äôs increasingly ‚Äúthe great companies‚Äù, full stop. But‚Ä¶ is it a bubble? At a16z Runtime late last year, we heard from Google that 7-8 year old TPUs are still running at 100% utilization‚Ä¶ And Jevons‚Äô Paradox is certainly real this time around. The cheaper the tokens get, the more they‚Äôre used - especially when indirectly monetized. All that‚Äôs to say, at the end of the day, it‚Äôs got to pay back. Here‚Äôs what that‚Äôll take: (Because a billion dollars isn‚Äôt cool. You know what‚Äôs cool? A trillion dollars.) You can view the whole deck here [ https://substack.com/redirect/3e7108f1-7eed-4350-8a52-b7634d5c8242?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]: Thanks for reading! If you don‚Äôt already subscribe, get more from a16z every weekday by clicking right here: This newsletter is provided for informational purposes only, and should not be relied upon as legal, business, investment, or tax advice. Furthermore, this content is not investment advice, nor is it intended for use by any investors or prospective investors in any a16z funds. This newsletter may link to other websites or contain other information obtained from third-party sources - a16z has not independently verified nor makes any representations about the current or enduring accuracy of such information. If this content includes third-party advertisements, a16z has not reviewed such advertisements and does not endorse any advertising content or related companies contained therein. Any investments or portfolio companies mentioned, referred to, or described are not representative of all investments in vehicles managed by a16z; visit https://a16z.com/investment-list/ [ https://substack.com/redirect/31fe7565-6c8c-4ae0-835c-f3aa0ca1a831?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] for a full list of investments. Other important information can be found at a16z.com/disclosures [ https://substack.com/redirect/55825200-efa2-4ed6-a856-03360d0a4e04?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ].
