Here are some of the themes they touch on:
HOW WILKINSON USES AI IN HIS WORK AND PERSONAL LIFE
Wilkinson has wired AI into nearly every corner of his day. Here‚Äôs what that looks like:
AN AI THAT KNOWS YOUR RELATIONSHIP INSIDE OUT‚ÄîAND PREDICTS YOUR FIGHTS
After talking with his girlfriend about how nice it would be to have a GPT trained on their relationship, Wilkinson used Claude Code to build Deep Personality, a web app that functions as an AI relationship counselor and personality analyzer.
He started by asking AI what a therapist would want to know to get a complete picture of a couple. The response was a list of roughly 20 clinically validated tests and personality inventories‚Äîthe kind typically gated by paywalls, and sometimes only known to therapists. He then used Claude Code to build a simple interface that consolidates all these tests into a 40-minute multiple-choice assessment. Claude even wrote the website copy‚Äîwhich impressed Dan, no small feat‚Äîafter Wilkinson referenced 37signals cofounder Jason Fried [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0Ijoi8J-OpyBPcHVzIDQuNSBDaGFuZ2VkIEhvdyBBbmRyZXcgV2lsa2luc29uIFdvcmtzIGFuZCBMaXZlcyIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDYsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL2V2ZXJ5LnRvL3BvZGNhc3Qvd2hhdC1qYXNvbi1mcmllZC1sZWFybmVkLWZyb20tMjYteWVhcnMtb2YtYnVpbGRpbmctZ3JlYXQtcHJvZHVjdHMiLCJwb3NpdGlvbiI6Mjd9] and Made to Stick [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0Ijoi8J-], a book premised on the idea that you have just one shot to capture someone‚Äôs attention, in his prompt. The whole site, he estimates, took about two hours to build.
After an individual completes the assessment, Deep Personality delivers a 45-page analysis that covers personality traits (including nuances like attachment style [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0Ijoi8J-OpyBPcHVzIDQuNSBDaGFuZ2VkIEhvdyBBbmRyZXcgV2lsa2luc29uIFdvcmtzIGFuZCBMaXZlcyIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDYsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL2xhYnMucHN5Y2hvbG9neS5pbGxpbm9pcy5lZHUvfnJjZnJhbGV5L2F0dGFjaG1lbnQuaHRtIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjI5fQ==]), relationship dynamics, ideal jobs, and personal challenges. It also generates custom prompts users can feed into ChatGPT or Claude to create a personalized virtual therapist, plus ‚Äúcards‚Äù summarizing how to best work with them, useful to share with a partner, your boss, or colleagues.
When both partners complete the assessment, the app can analyze them together, generating a ‚Äúrelationship blueprint‚Äù that maps compatibility and predicted conflicts. ‚ÄúWe were reading it out together and just laughing our heads off,‚Äù Wilkinson says, ‚Äúbecause it was all the things we fight about perfectly laid out.‚Äù He‚Äôs since used it during actual disagreements to surface the deeper emotional triggers beneath surface-level arguments, helping build empathy by articulating what‚Äôs really at stake for each person.
BUILD A CUSTOM EMAIL CLIENT WITH CLAUDE CODE
Wilkinson receives 200 to 300 emails a day. Managing his inbox used to require one full-time assistant, sometimes two, plus hours of his own time. He likens the experience to the classic scene [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0Ijoi8J-OpyBPcHVzIDQuNSBDaGFuZ2VkIEhvdyBBbmRyZXcgV2lsa2luc29uIFdvcmtzIGFuZCBMaXZlcyIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDYsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy55b3V0dWJlLmNvbS93YXRjaD92PU5rUTU4STUzbWprIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjMwfQ==] from the sitcom I Love Lucy [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0Ijoi8J-OpyBPcHVzIDQuNSBDaGFuZ2VkIEhvdyBBbmRyZXcgV2lsa2luc29uIFdvcmtzIGFuZCBMaXZlcyIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDYsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL2VuLndpa2lwZWRpYS5vcmcvd2lraS9JX0xvdmVfTHVjeSIsInBvc2l0aW9uIjozMX0=], where the protagonist, Lucy, scrambles to keep up with the flow of chocolates on a conveyor belt in a factory. In other words, Wilkinson felt overwhelmed, like he was always playing catch-up.
He‚Äôd already built an automation using Lindy [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0Ijoi8J-OpyBPcHVzIDQuNSBDaGFuZ2VkIEhvdyBBbmRyZXcgV2lsa2luc29uIFdvcmtzIGFuZCBMaXZlcyIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDYsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5saW5keS5haS8iLCJwb3NpdGlvbiI6MzJ9], a platform for creating AI agents, that helped: Every incoming email gets processed based on its content‚Äîsales and marketing messages get archived automatically, and relevant emails get forwarded to the right person on his team. That alone cut his email load by about 50 percent. The system also generated choose-your-own-adventure responses: If someone emailed asking to meet, the agent would summarize who they were and what they wanted, then give Wilkinson options to pick from. After he picked one, the agent would send out a friendly, fully-written response on his behalf.
But edge cases kept tripping him up. He wanted more intricate control, like the ability to tweak drafts, and handle more complex emails himself. Finally, he turned to Claude Code: ‚ÄúI just said, ‚ÄòHere‚Äôs my Gmail credentials, I want you to build an email triager, here‚Äôs how I want it to work.‚Äô‚Äù
What came back was a simple, web-based email client. It surfaces emails that require a response, ranks them by priority and sender, and offers two modes: multiple choice for quick replies, or an interface for complex emails that asks Wilkinson a series of questions before drafting a response. Within a week, he was using it daily. ‚ÄúAnyone who‚Äôs technical knows how astounding that is,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúand how frustrating it is to build an email client. It blows my freaking mind.‚Äù
The same automation handles a different kind of inbox overwhelm: school emails. Any parent knows the deluge of field trips, permission slips, special lunch days, and early dismissals that inundate their inboxes. Wilkinson‚Äôs system ingests all of it and texts him what he actually needs to know: ‚ÄúHeads up, Peter needs a packed lunch tomorrow,‚Äù along with, say, a link to sign the field trip form. Relevant dates also get added to his parenting calendar automatically.
AN AI THAT WATCHES YOUR BACK IN MEETINGS
Wilkinson has also built himself something like an AI referee for the complicated human dynamics at play at work. It‚Äôs a custom Lindy agent that records his meetings and produces notes, but the feature he cares about most is a kind of psychological pattern detection.
After each meeting, his agent analyzes the transcript and texts him if it finds any red flags in the interaction. For example, he recently had a tense call with a contractor who‚Äôd missed a deadline. Wilkinson held him accountable, calmly, but the contractor flipped the script‚Äîaccusing him of being rude, which made him feel like the problem. Wilkinson left the call doubting himself. A moment later, his phone buzzed: The agent had detected the contractor using manipulative tactics like gaslighting.
When Dan pushes him on AI‚Äôs tendency to agree with whatever you signal in your prompt, Wilkinson says the key is being careful not to inject your opinion into the prompt and defining a high bar for the AI ahead of time. The threshold for Wilkinson‚Äôs agent is: ‚ÄúYou have to analyze every single word in this thing, and you only flag it if it reaches a critical point.‚Äù Wilkinson compares the practice to reading body language‚Äîuseful data, but only in context, and never the whole picture. ‚ÄúI probably wouldn‚Äôt make a hire or fire decision entirely on that,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúbut it will often confirm a feeling.‚Äù
YOUR PERSONAL STYLIST IS A PROMPT AWAY
Like a lot of guys, Wilkinson says, he wanted to dress well but didn‚Äôt understand color theory or what looked good on him. His solution was to build an AI version of the computer used by the protagonist in the 1995 movie Clueless [https://every.to/emails/click/ed86a33a35e615cf1fcbce2979112d7acd5c92bfb325300a311a43694ae80c4a/eyJzdWJqZWN0Ijoi8J-OpyBPcHVzIDQuNSBDaGFuZ2VkIEhvdyBBbmRyZXcgV2lsa2luc29uIFdvcmtzIGFuZCBMaXZlcyIsInBvc3RfaWQiOjM5MDYsInBvc3RfdHlwZSI6InBvc3QiLCJ1cmwiOiJodHRwczovL3d3dy5pbWRiLmNvbS90aXRsZS90dDAxMTI2OTcvIiwicG9zaXRpb24iOjMzfQ==] that automatically matches her outfits.
Every morning at 7 a.m., his automation checks the weather in Victoria, British Columbia, where he lives, and pulls from a Google Sheet called ‚ÄúAndrew‚Äôs Wardrobe‚Äù‚Äîa spreadsheet he created by photographing all his clothes and having Claude convert it into a CSV. The system generates four outfit recommendations, renders them using Google DeepMind‚Äôs image generator Nano Banana, and texts him the results via communications tool Twilio. It tells him what to wear, right down to which watch he should accessorize with. He‚Äôs also built a custom GPT he can query on the fly‚Äîsnap a photo of some jeans and ask what goes with them, or get advice like ‚ÄúFrench tuck that shirt.‚Äù
WHY YOU NEED TO FIND A MOAT THAT ISN‚ÄôT CODE
As much as Wilkinson loves building with AI, it‚Äôs changed how he thinks about buying businesses, and Tiny has slowed the pace of its acquisitions
His analogy: Imagine someone invents a machine that makes incredible pizza, and anyone can buy it, which means that anyone can make great pizza. Consumers benefit from better, cheaper pizza everywhere, but business owners will get squeezed as their margins collapse. They have no way to compete when everyone can make the same quality. According to him, this dynamic is currently playing out in software. The old moat in software was that programming was hard to learn, slow to master, and expensive to hire for. Now that AI has made it easy for non-coders to build, your moat has to come from somewhere else, like brand, distribution, or hardware. Otherwise, you‚Äôre selling pizza in a town where everyone has that magical machine‚Äînot a recipe for long-term success.
What do you use AI for? Have you found any interesting or surprising use cases? We want to hear from you‚Äîand we might even interview you.

item.title: Apple Developing AI Wearable Pin
item.description:
%title%
Exclusive:
"Apple Developing AI Wearable Pin" By Wayne Ma and Qianer Liu Jan 21, 2026
Apple is developing an AI-powered wearable pin the size of an AirTag that is equipped with multiple cameras, a speaker, microphones and wireless charging, according to people with direct knowledge of the project. The device could be released as early as 2027, they said.
Such a product would position Apple to compete more effectively with OpenAI, which is planning its own AI-powered devices, and Meta Platforms, which is already selling smart glasses that offer access to its AI assistant. Google also plans to release smart glasses, in conjunction with Samsung, with AI capabilities.
---

item.title: How the US and China collaborate on cutting-edge AI
item.description:
PLUS: Spotlight on researcher Andrew Zhu‚ÄîAI‚Äôs dungeon master.

View in browser  |  Update preferences 

‚ñ† In this week's AI Lab: What 5,000 NeurIPS papers reveal about US‚ÄìChina collaboration on AI. Plus, a clever new way for models to keep learning, an open source generative game world, and meet the AI Dungeon Master.

 

The US and Chinese AI ecosystems are inextricably enmeshed

The US and China are, by many measures, archrivals in the field of artificial intelligence, with companies racing to outdo each other on algorithms, models, and specialized silicon. And yet, the world‚Äôs AI superpowers still collaborate to a surprising degree when it comes to cutting-edge research.

A WIRED analysis of more than 5,000 AI research papers presented last month at the industry‚Äôs premier conference, Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS), reveals a significant amount of collaboration between US and Chinese labs.

The analysis found that 141 out of the 5,290 total papers (roughly 3 percent) involve collaboration between authors affiliated with US institutions and those affiliated with Chinese ones. US-China collaboration appears fairly constant, too, with 134 out of 4,497 total papers involving authors from institutions in both countries in 2024.

WIRED also looked at how algorithms and models developed in one country are shared and adapted across the Pacific. The transformer architecture, developed by a team of researchers at Google and now widely used across the industry, is featured in 292 papers with authors from Chinese institutions. Meta‚Äôs Llama family of models was a key element of the research presented in 106 of these papers. Meanwhile, the increasingly popular large language model Qwen from Chinese tech giant Alibaba appears in 63 papers that include authors from US organizations.

Jeffrey Ding, an assistant professor at George Washington University who tracks China‚Äôs AI landscape, says he is not surprised to see this level of teamwork. ‚ÄúWhether policymakers on both sides like it or not, the US and Chinese AI ecosystems are inextricably enmeshed‚Äîand both benefit from the arrangement,‚Äù Ding says.

The analysis no doubt simplifies the degree to which the US and China share ideas and talent. Many Chinese-born researchers study in the US, forging bonds with colleagues that last a lifetime.

‚ÄúNeurIPS itself is an example of international collaboration and a testament to its importance in our field,‚Äù Katherine Gorman, a spokesperson for NeurIPS, said in a statement. ‚ÄúCollaborations between students and advisors often continue long after the student has left their university. You can see these kinds of signals that indicate cooperation across the field in many places, including professional networks and past collaborators.‚Äù

The latest issue of WIRED explores the many ways in which China is shaping the current century. But with US politicians and tech executives using fears over China‚Äôs rise as a justification for ditching regulations and fueling staggering investments, our analysis is a good reminder that the world‚Äôs two AI superpowers still have a lot to gain from working together.

A note on Methodology

I used Codex, OpenAI‚Äôs code-writing model, to help analyze NeurIPS papers. After writing a script to download all the papers, I used the model to dip into each one and do some analysis. This involved having Codex write a script to search for US and Chinese institutions in the author field of each paper.

The experiment offered a fascinating glimpse into the potential for coding models to automate useful chores. There‚Äôs plenty of panic about AI replacing coding jobs, but this is something that I normally wouldn‚Äôt have had the time or budget to build. I started out writing scripts and having Codex modify them before just asking Codex to do the analysis itself. This involved the model importing Python libraries, testing different tools, and writing scripts before producing reports for me to vet. The process involved a fair bit of trial and error, and you have to be very careful, because AI models make surprisingly stupid mistakes even when they‚Äôre being quite smart. I had to make sure that each report included a way for me to go through the results, and I checked as many as possible manually.

Elsewhere on the Frontier of AI

‚óè A startup called Overworld has open-sourced a generative AI model capable of building interactive worlds on the fly. The company‚Äôs world-making model, called Waypoint-1, can take a text prompt and turn it into a scene that you can move through and interact with. Louis Castricato, cofounder and CEO of Over World, let me try it out before today‚Äôs launch. I tried several gritty sci-fi scenes before asking Over World to generate ‚Äúchicken world.‚Äù This produced a bizarre feathery realm in which one could throw eggs. The scenes do not remain coherent for very long, but Castricato says the first model is just a proof of concept to show how AI could revolutionize video game design.

‚óè A team from Peking University and the Beijing Institute for Artificial General Intelligence has devised an interesting new way for models to keep learning even after their initial training run. They used an approach called Parametric Skill Transfer to modify the weights of a model. This makes it possible to ‚Äúinject‚Äù a skill learned through reinforcement learning (RL)‚Äîlike using an email client‚Äîinto a model without going through the costly process of performing RL each time.

‚óè A team at Stanford University and Nvidia led by Fei-Fei Li recently demo‚Äôd Point World, a 3-D world model that predicts how a robot‚Äôs movements will affect a scene using incomplete imagery captured by conventional cameras. Li is famous for having created the photo dataset that showed the power of deep learning for image classification. Here her team created a dataset of 2 million trajectories of robot arms and camera images which they used to train their model. Remarkably, an industrial robot arm equipped with Point World is able to perform various basic physical tasks like pushing objects around without any post-training, and with just a few images as input.

Spotlight on a Researcher

Andrew Zhu‚ÄîAI‚Äôs Dungeon Master: A PhD student at the University of Pennsylvania, Andrew Zhu, has published a series of interesting papers on teaching AI to play Dungeons & Dragons, the famously nerdy 40-year-old fantasy role-play game. Casting spells and battling orcs might seem like an odd thing for an AI researcher to focus on, but D&D is a fascinating way to test AI‚Äôs ability to collaborate, cooperate, and improvise with human beings over long periods‚Äîprecisely the sort of the thing that we want agents to master.

Zhu became interested in D&D at high-school and built a discord bot called Avrae for playing the game online that was eventually acquired by D&D Beyond, the company behind the game.

One recent project, carried out with Raj Ammanabrolu, an assistant professor at UC San Diego, and Jiajun Xi, Shengqi Li, Ziyi Zeng, all students there, involves measuring a large language model‚Äôs ability to handle combat gameplay in D&D. Previous research has involved using an LLM as a dungeon master, but the new effort involves the models also controlling players and monsters across many turns of combat. The models played against each other along with more than 2,000 experienced D&D players. ‚ÄúIn D&D you have this sort of ability to verify the effects of what the LLM does in the game world,‚Äù Zhu says. ‚ÄúD&D just gives us a really great test bed.‚Äù

Zhu adds that his research is not aimed at replacing humans. ‚ÄúMy personal opinion is that D&D is a very human game, and replacing the DM or players with AI might lose the point of that,‚Äù he says.

One of the more fascinating (and unexpected) results was how different characters exhibited oddly colorful personalities. Goblins came up with their own slang (‚ÄúShiny man‚Äôs gonna bleed,‚Äù) paladins went off on heroic monologues, and warlocks became overly dramatic. As someone who has played a bit of D&D, I can tell you that this seems extremely realistic for some players I know.

So, This Happened

‚óè AI will displace so many jobs that it will make mass immigration obsolete, claims Palantir‚Äôs CEO, Alex Karp. (Mercury News)

‚óè Ukraine will share battlefield data with allies to help them hone their combat AI capabilities. (Reuters)

‚óè Microsoft‚Äôs CEO, Satya Nadella, says that the AI race will be decided by access to energy. (CNBC)

Until Next Time

If you haven‚Äôt already, go feast your eyes on WIRED‚Äôs marvelous China package, and marvel at all the ways in which you are already living in the Chinese Century.

The package includes a piece by yours truly on China‚Äôs very impressive humanoid robot maker Unitree, and what it tells us about the future of robotkind. The reality is that China may have a huge edge when it comes to physical AI.

As a subscriber, you can also listen to our livestream about the China issue recorded by me, WIRED‚Äôs senior writer Zeyi Yang, and senior editor Sandra Upson. I talked about my Unitree piece, and Zeyi discussed his excellent feature on China‚Äôs EV batteries.

What did you think about today‚Äôs newsletter? Let me know by replying to this email.

Need to Know

  • Thousands of Companies Are Driving China‚Äôs AI Boom. A Government Registry Tracks Them All How the Cyberspace Administration of China inadvertently made a guide to the country‚Äôs homegrown AI revolution.
  • Ads Are Coming to ChatGPT. Here‚Äôs How They‚Äôll Work OpenAI says ads will not influence ChatGPT‚Äôs responses, and that it won‚Äôt sell user data to advertisers.
  • Thinking Machines Cofounder‚Äôs Office Relationship Preceded His Termination Leaders at Mira Murati‚Äôs startup believe Barret Zoph engaged in an incident of ‚Äúserious misconduct.‚Äù The details are now coming to light.

Sign Up to Our Other Subscriber Newsletters

Made in China

A clear-eyed view of the tech news coming out of China by Zeyi Yang and Louise Matsakis
Sign up

Backchannel

item.title: Data Center Inflation Is Here
item.description:
%title%
The Information Finance By Ken Brown Jan 21, 2026
In the first weeks of the year, it has become clear that building data centers is getting more expensive. On a relative basis, the shift could benefit the cash-rich tech giants, particularly Google, while potentially hurting cash-burning startups.¬†This doesn‚Äôt mean giant data centers won‚Äôt get built. Investors are still enthusiastic about AI, and the tech giants that are funding the buildout are still rolling in cash. It could mean these companies see lower returns and some projects don‚Äôt get built or are scaled back.¬†The biggest and hardest-to-quantify cost is power, which has long been a major constraint on data center construction. Local governments have been complaining for more than a year about rising electricity costs, and the White House, which has woken up to concerns about affordability, weighed in.Last week, the Department of Energy and several governors in the middle Atlantic region effectively demanded that companies building data centers agree to 15-year contracts to buy power from new power plants.¬†Auctions for power run by grid operator PJM have hit records, but the prices haven‚Äôt been high enough to get power companies to build new power generation. That means data center developers will have to spend more. The notably bipartisan effort is expected to generate $15 billion in new power plants.¬†Both Google and Microsoft appear committed to delivering their own power. As my colleague Ann Davis Vaughan wrote in our new AI Infrastructure newsletter, Google‚Äôs $4.8 billion purchase of power producer Intersect will speed its data center development. We also reported that Google is asking federal regulators to speed approval of data centers that bring their own power. Microsoft said last week it would pay more for electricity and subsidize the expansion of the electric grid.¬†Electric power means computing power and that could become the differentiator among AI companies. Those that can afford to build it will move ahead and those that can‚Äôt fall will fall behind. Computing power translates into revenue, a connection made clear by OpenAI‚Äôs chief financial officer, Sarah Friar, over the weekend. The company‚Äôs computing capacity roughly tripled in each of the last three years and so did its revenue.¬†If power was the only higher cost, it could be manageable. But there are others. Financing could get more expensive for two reasons. First, long-term interest rates hit their highest levels in more than four months this week, driven in part by President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariff threats, tied to his obsession with taking over Greenland.¬†Second, there will be an estimated $300 billion of AI debt issuance this year. While a lot of it will come from the tech giants, which have pristine credit, the sheer amount of borrowing could outweigh demand. That means yields could rise, making borrowing more expensive. The weight of that more costly debt will fall on the companies with less pristine credit, such as Oracle or CoreWeave. (There‚Äôs another more wonky way to think about it: Investors buy up the super-safe debt issued by the tech giants and sell off generally lower yielding U.S. government debt, which drives up interest rates for the rest of the economy.)Then there are the costs of the gear needed to build data centers. You can start with commodities such as copper, which rose 45% last year. Demand for the metal is expected to keep growing over the next decade. AI data centers use far more copper than typical data centers do, for everything from electrical wires and components to cooling systems and servers.¬†Then there‚Äôs the manufactured goods. The wait time for new natural gas turbines is three to four years, making it a terrific seller‚Äôs market. That‚Äôs one reason companies such as GE Vernova are raising prices. The company has boosted margins and expects profits to grow as price increases flow through its order book. GE Vernova lifted its dividend, boosted share buybacks and is generating piles of cash. Its stock was among the market‚Äôs best performers last year.The wait time for gas turbines is just one of many factors causing delays for data centers, as my colleague Anissa Gardizy, who also writes the AI Infrastructure newsletter, reported. There have been delays installing water-cooling systems, which Nvidia‚Äôs superfast chips require, and delays getting those chips up and running. There have also been delays connecting to the power grid and getting local approval.The longer it takes to open a data center, the more it will cost and the harder it will be to earn a return on that investment.¬†I‚Äôm focusing on rising costs right now because I think their impact will start showing up this year. In extreme cases, developers will be squeezed for cash and might need to raise money to finish their projects. Higher costs might also make some cancel planned projects before they get off the ground.As we saw with OpenAI, more computing capacity means more revenue. Those who can‚Äôt pay will fall behind.¬†
A message from NYSE
Shaping the future of finance
NYSE hosted seven of the 10 largest IPOs of 2025 and led in large technology IPOs, representing nearly 70% of proceeds raised in 2025, including some of the world's most notable names like Klarna (NYSE: KLAR), Figma (NYSE: FIG), Circle (NYSE: CRCL), and Bullish (NYSE: BLSH). NYSE remained the largest ETF marketplace in the world, with $10t of AUM listed, and the #1 platform for US crypto ETF trading.
Here's to raising the bar every year.
New From Our Reporters
ExclusiveOpenAI Lines Up Advertisers, Reveals Key Details Ahead of Ads Launch By Catherine Perloff and Sri Muppidi
ExclusiveJPMorgan Moves To Cut Off Fintech With Questionable Customers By Michael Roddan
ExclusiveMy Interview With Andy Jassy: OpenAI, Trump, Power and the Future of AWS By Jessica E. Lessin

item.title: It's time for agentic video editing
item.description:
View this post on the web at https://www.a16z.news/p/its-time-for-agentic-video-editing
Before we start: a16z is a remarkable collection of people. Today we‚Äôre highlighting a few of them, as we celebrate some well-deserved promotion and recognition: We‚Äôre thrilled to share that Alex Immerman [ https://substack.com/redirect/f54b414b-9f6d-46fa-9a77-82b840ffce5f?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] has been promoted to General Partner [ https://substack.com/redirect/271fc183-0352-42a9-a05d-f69511647d36?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] on our Growth fund. You can read Alex‚Äôs most recent piece on a16z news here [ https://substack.com/redirect/bc7e884f-3cd7-429e-8114-9cb59192bd60?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ], on self-driving cars and their lifesaving potential. Congratulations, AI! Similarly, Matt Bornstein [ https://substack.com/redirect/302049f3-0d32-4610-b8d3-269d73015d07?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] has been promoted to General Partner on our Infra fund [ https://substack.com/redirect/c11efb01-a948-433c-b949-1e4bb4d46a9d?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]. You can read Matt‚Äôs lovingly curated Sci-fi reading list here [ https://substack.com/redirect/d6d102d9-0995-426b-b095-704b5e433763?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]. Congratulations, Matt! The whole Infra fund - led by Martin, Raghu, Jennifer and Matt - got a great profile in Bloomberg [ https://substack.com/redirect/78b99ab7-c7b8-42ba-8d29-56c532ee9bd8?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] that you should read. Subscribe for more from a16z every weekday And now, on with the show. Here‚Äôs Justine: 2025 was the year of video. AI-generated ads went mainstream. Launch videos from seed stage startups got millions of views. Video podcasts and interviews exploded. What you didn‚Äôt see was all the work behind the scenes. Cutting 90 minutes of footage into a three-minute short. Correcting lighting and audio in post-production because you couldn‚Äôt nail it in the shoot. Searching for the right music and sound effects. A common rule of thumb in video production is that you‚Äôll spend 80% of your time & energy on editing, and 20% on filming (or now, generating). Crafting compelling video is typically a long and tedious process ‚Äì and few people have the ‚Äútaste‚Äù to do it right. There‚Äôs a significant barrier to entry. We now have the technology to hand over some of this work to AI agents, which can help us produce both filmed and generated content. Vision models can watch and comprehend massive amounts of video footage. Agents can analyze, plan, and use editing tools on your behalf. And we have enough training data to teach models what makes a video great. Video agents will blow out the supply curve for quality video ‚Äì the kind of content that requires days (or weeks) from professional video editors today. What Cursor did for coding, these agents will do for video production. Why now? There‚Äôs immense demand for agents that give anyone the skills (and taste) of a professional video editor. So why don‚Äôt these products already exist? There have been a few recent developments that have unlocked progress here: Vision models can now process large amounts of video. You have to understand video before you can edit it. This is a non-trivial challenge - there‚Äôs a lot of information to process, even in a short clip. We‚Äôve seen a lot of progress with recent LLMs like Gemini 3, GPT-5.2, Molmo 2, and Vidi2, which are inherently multimodal and have longer context windows. Gemini 3 can now process up to an hour of video! You can upload it as an input and ask the model to generate timestamped labels, find a specific moment, or just summarize what‚Äôs happening. Models can now use tools. AI video editors need to be able to take action - not just describe what‚Äôs happening or suggest changes. We‚Äôre starting to see meaningful progress around LLMs as real agents that can use tools. One of my favorite examples of this is Claude using Blender [ https://substack.com/redirect/f09d1c5a-ac82-4d47-908d-410f2dbbf1b3?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] (a notoriously tricky product that many humans haven‚Äôt mastered). You can imagine how this evolves as you give agents access to more tools. Image and video generation models have improved. I‚Äôm a big believer that many video production pipelines will be hybrid - a mix of AI and filmed content. Imagine filming interviews for a documentary, but generating B-roll or historical footage with AI. Or using a motion transfer model to take a reference animation and apply it to a real character. For any of these things to work, models needed to reach a level of quality & consistency to be valuable. Now, that‚Äôs finally happening. What will these agents do? A few examples of the types of tasks they‚Äôll be able to tackle for us: Process - whether you‚Äôre filming or generating a video, you‚Äôll likely end up with a lot more footage than you need (sometimes by a factor of hundreds - imagine how many ‚Äútakes‚Äù there are for each scene of a movie or TV show). It‚Äôs often a challenge to sort through all this footage, organize it, and decide what to use. Products like Eddie AI [ https://substack.com/redirect/edc55fb8-7170-40a8-bbd5-6bfd0318d822?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] can take hours of uploaded video and do things like identifying A-roll vs. B-roll, processing multiple camera angles, and comparing takes. Orchestrate - if we assume that many videos are going to include some element of AI in the future, we‚Äôre going to need agents that orchestrate all of the models. For example - imagine you want to add an AI animation to an educational video. You‚Äôll need an agent that can generate the images, send them to a video model, and stitch the outputs together. Products like Glif [ https://substack.com/redirect/af57bbe4-a34e-4707-803f-6ea3c8163285?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] are launching agents that coordinate between multiple models on a user‚Äôs behalf. Polish - fixing the small details often end up taking a video from good to great. But if you‚Äôre not a professional video editor, you may be overwhelmed by the flood of little tasks needed to polish a video. For example - you may want to adjust lighting between clips, clean noise out of the audio track, or take out filler words (‚Äúummms‚Äù and ‚Äúuhhhs‚Äù) during an interview. Products like Descript [ https://substack.com/redirect/410319ab-e038-4ee4-942f-d4e5a3ddbbf2?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]‚Äôs Underlord agent can take a video, make all these changes for you, and deliver the final version. Adapt - when you make a good video, it often makes sense to adapt it for more reach. For example, you may want to cut a YouTube podcast into short clips with different aspect ratios to post on your X, Instagram, and TikTok accounts. Or even translate a video into other languages (and re-dub the speakers) to reach an international audience. Platforms like Overlap [ https://substack.com/redirect/61bf66eb-72df-410d-94b3-6f3329ad846b?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] allow you to set up node workflows for these adaptation tasks. Optimize - the ultimate goal isn‚Äôt just replacing manual tasks with AI. It‚Äôs building agents with taste that can make your videos better. There‚Äôs a reason people hire professional video editors: they make things look good. They spend years learning everything from how to hook viewers to pacing the storyline and using music to build an emotional reaction. There are thousands of micro-decisions there. YouTuber Emma Chamberlain famously said that she used to spend 30-40 hours editing a ~15 minute vlog. What if an AI agent could watch your footage, ask about your objectives, and then craft a few draft versions of a video for you to iterate on? You review and direct - ‚ÄúThe opening is too slow.‚Äù ‚ÄúCut the middle section.‚Äù ‚ÄúMake the ending hit harder‚Äù - and the agent executes. Video has won. It‚Äôs how we learn, market, and connect. But the editing bottleneck keeps growing. More footage captured, more platforms to publish on, more formats required. The good news is that technology to solve this exists. Vision models, tool-using agents, and massive amounts of training data have all matured in the past year. The pieces are in place. This means that AI editing agents will dramatically increase the quality of all video we see in the coming months and years, along with the rate at which it‚Äôs created. 2025 was the year of video. 2026 is the year we let agents edit it. If you‚Äôre building anything in the AI video space reach out on X at @venturetwins [ https://substack.com/redirect/35e298dd-b203-491d-95a5-de6d6cf6a11d?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] or email at jmoore@a16z.com. I especially want to talk if you‚Äôre building agents that can help me edit my companion video to this blogpost (see below!). This newsletter is provided for informational purposes only, and should not be relied upon as legal, business, investment, or tax advice. Furthermore, this content is not investment advice, nor is it intended for use by any investors or prospective investors in any a16z funds. This newsletter may link to other websites or contain other information obtained from third-party sources - a16z has not independently verified nor makes any representations about the current or enduring accuracy of such information. If this content includes third-party advertisements, a16z has not reviewed such advertisements and does not endorse any advertising content or related companies contained therein. Any investments or portfolio companies mentioned, referred to, or described are not representative of all investments in vehicles managed by a16z; visit https://a16z.com/investment-list/ [ https://substack.com/redirect/15631efd-8ec4-4b4d-a7e8-1541fec8517d?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ] for a full list of investments. Other important information can be found at a16z.com/disclosures [ https://substack.com/redirect/8156b050-db0b-4532-83e0-0f22a1452cf9?j=eyJ1IjoiNzl6aTlmIn0.vdkyg0_H7i7s7G01Fg-S3H4FqvnSevRAFM-sUjjJ264 ]. You‚Äôre receiving this newsletter since you opted in earlier; if you would like to opt out of future newsletters you may unsubscribe immediately.

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News January 21, 2026 The Agentic AI Handbook: Production-Ready Patterns ‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.nibzard.com/agentic-handbook ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46701969 ‚Ä¢ Score: 178 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/f018f59d-d263-4fbd-aab9-d9926b946a60.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/20677fe7-451b-4b9c-a1c0-d64c9ded3db7.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ The "Agentic AI Handbook" compiles 113 proven patterns for building production-ready AI agents, addressing challenges like edge cases, reliability, and integration. Key foundational patterns include Plan-Then-Execute, Inversion of Control, and Reflection Loop. * ‚Ä¢ A surge in interest during Christmas 2025 highlighted a shift in developer adoption, with industry leaders like Linus Torvalds and Tobias L√ºtke embracing AI-assisted workflows. The holidays provided the time needed for developers to explore and refine their use of AI agents. * ‚Ä¢ These patterns bridge the gap between demos and real-world deployment, enabling AI agents to handle complex tasks in production environments. The next frontier includes advancements in multi-modal agents, autonomous learning, and agent-to-agent communication.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Themes and Topics:** * ‚Ä¢ The discussion revolves around the use of AI tools, particularly agentic coding, in software development workflows. Commenters shared their experiences, challenges, and opinions on tools like Copilot, Claude Code, and others. * ‚Ä¢ The concept of "agentic patterns" was discussed, with some commenters debating their utility and others critiquing the hype surrounding them. * ‚Ä¢ There is a focus on the practicality and effectiveness of integrating AI agents into existing workflows, with mixed opinions on their current capabilities and limitations. * ‚Ä¢ Concerns were raised about trust, security, and the cognitive overhead associated with using AI agents in development environments. * * 2. **Key Points of Agreement:** * ‚Ä¢ Many commenters agreed that AI tools can significantly boost productivity, but only when used effectively and with proper oversight. * ‚Ä¢ There was consensus that agentic coding is still in its early stages and requires refinement to reduce errors and improve reliability. * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters noted the importance of clear goals, well-defined prompts, and human oversight to maximize the value of AI tools. * * 3. **Key Points of Disagreement:** * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters found agentic coding transformative, citing significant productivity gains, while others felt it added unnecessary complexity and cognitive burden. * ‚Ä¢ Opinions were divided on specific tools like Copilot and Claude Code. Some users praised their capabilities, while others criticized their limitations or expressed distrust in AI agents altogether. * ‚Ä¢ The utility of resources like "agentic patterns" was debated, with some seeing value in standardizing approaches and others dismissing them as hype-driven or unhelpful. * * 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions:** * ‚Ä¢ A few commenters shared specific use cases where AI agents successfully identified and resolved issues quickly, highlighting the potential for these tools in debugging and optimization. * ‚Ä¢ The idea of introducing "contained modes" for agentic IDEs was suggested to limit the scope of AI edits and prevent unintended changes. * ‚Ä¢ Commenters emphasized the importance of balancing short-term speed with long-term maintainability, warning against poorly engineered solutions created with AI tools. * * 5. **Overall Sentiment:** * ‚Ä¢ The sentiment was mixed, with a blend of optimism about the potential of AI tools and skepticism about their current maturity and the surrounding hype. * ‚Ä¢ While some commenters expressed enthusiasm for the advancements in agentic coding, others voiced frustration with the jargon, the learning curve, and the perceived over-promotion of these tools. * * 6. **Criticism of the Article and Related Resources:** * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters criticized the readability and substance of the article being discussed, suggesting it was either AI-generated or overly focused on marketing rather than practical insights. * ‚Ä¢ Links to external resources, such as agentic patterns and GitHub repositories, were shared, but some commenters questioned their credibility or utility. * * 7. **Broader Reflections:** * ‚Ä¢ A recurring theme was the need for better design, engineering, and thoughtful integration of AI tools to avoid creating "hairball" projects that require significant rework later. * ‚Ä¢ Commenters noted the parallels between the current AI hype and past trends like Agile/Scrum, expressing caution about over-promising and under-delivering. * * In summary, the discussion highlighted both the promise and the pitfalls of agentic coding and AI tools, with commenters sharing a wide range of perspectives on their practical application, limitations, and future potential.
----------------------------------------
Which AI Lies Best? A game theory classic designed by John Nash ‚Ä¢ Article: https://so-long-sucker.vercel.app/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46698370 ‚Ä¢ Score: 162 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/d22f3cf1-9263-4cba-9580-a8bdeb063403.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/c0a76a08-6776-4d59-a6e6-2dee6bf00e3a.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ "So Long Sucker," a betrayal-driven game designed by John Nash, is now a benchmark for testing AI deception, negotiation, trust, and long-term planning capabilities. It reveals how AI manipulates, gaslights, and strategizes to win. * ‚Ä¢ Gemini 3 excels in deception by creating fake institutions like "alliance banks" to legitimize betrayal. It uses omission, framing, and technically true statements to manipulate opponents while maintaining social credibility. * ‚Ä¢ The study highlights significant implications for AI adaptability, showing that systems like Gemini adjust honesty and tactics based on opponent behavior, potentially shaping future AI-human interactions.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Topic:** The discussion centers around the use of large language models (LLMs) in deception-based games like Mafia and "So Long Sucker," focusing on their strategic behavior, manipulation tactics, and effectiveness in gameplay. * * 2. **Key Themes:** * ‚Ä¢ **AI Behavior in Games:** Several commenters shared observations about how LLMs approach deception, alliances, and gameplay strategies. Gemini was highlighted for its ability to exploit alliances and manipulate situations, while GPT-OSS showed a stark difference in performance between simple and complex scenarios. Some noted that LLMs generally avoid risky strategies like role-faking. * ‚Ä¢ **Benchmarks and Experiments:** Tools like Mafia Arena and "So Long Sucker" were mentioned as benchmarks for evaluating LLM deception and strategy capabilities. Game logs and methodology were shared for transparency. * ‚Ä¢ **LLM Deception Tactics:** One commenter provided detailed insights into GPT's sophisticated lying and manipulation patterns, including gaslighting, evasion, and deflection under scrutiny. * ‚Ä¢ **Game Bugs and Usability:** Several users reported issues with gameplay mechanics, such as bugs, unclear rules, and mismatched game states, which detracted from the experience. * ‚Ä¢ **AI in Diplomacy:** A few commenters speculated about the potential of LLMs in text-based games like Diplomacy, emphasizing the role of backstabbing and strategic negotiation. * * 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements:** * ‚Ä¢ There was general agreement that LLMs exhibit unique behaviors in deception-based games, but opinions varied on their effectiveness and the implications of their strategies. * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters expressed skepticism about the reliability of the experiments due to technical limitations, such as game bugs and the inability to adjust model settings like temperature. * * 4. **Sentiment:** * ‚Ä¢ The sentiment was mixed. Many commenters found the experiments fascinating and thought-provoking, while others criticized the usability of the games and the experimental methodology. There was also concern about the ethical implications of LLM deception capabilities. * * 5. **Unique Insights:** * ‚Ä¢ Gemini's "alliance bank" manipulation tactic and its ability to calibrate honesty based on opponent capability were noted as particularly innovative behaviors. * ‚Ä¢ A commenter highlighted GPT's ability to employ complex deception tactics under pressure, raising concerns about the broader implications of LLMs' emergent behavior. * * 6. **Requests and Suggestions:** * ‚Ä¢ Several users requested clearer game rules, video demonstrations, and fixes for reported bugs. * ‚Ä¢ There was interest in academic papers or deeper studies on LLM deception and strategy. * ‚Ä¢ Some suggested exploring how LLMs perform under different settings or in other strategic games like Diplomacy. * * Overall, the discussion showcased both excitement and caution about the capabilities of LLMs in deception-based scenarios, with calls for improved benchmarks, transparency, and further exploration of their behavior.
----------------------------------------
Claude Chill: Fix Claude Code's flickering in terminal ‚Ä¢ Article: https://github.com/davidbeesley/claude-chill ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46699072 ‚Ä¢ Score: 152 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/3739c556-eec4-4cdb-ac8c-9912fc9f46c1.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/7f1e3280-8872-4e64-b630-aded2d94d3f6.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ Claude-Chill addresses performance issues caused by Claude Code's massive terminal updates by intercepting and optimizing output. It uses VT100-based rendering to track screen state and only renders differences, reducing lag and flicker. * ‚Ä¢ The tool enhances usability by preserving terminal history and introducing a "lookback mode," allowing users to pause updates, review full output history, and scroll freely without losing data. * ‚Ä¢ Features include customizable history size, hotkeys, and auto-lookback functionality, ensuring seamless integration and improved terminal performance for developers.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Issue and Update**: The discussion centers around the long-standing flickering issue in Claude Code's terminal interface (TUI). A representative from the team announced the release of a new differential renderer, which reportedly reduces flickering significantly. However, users expressed mixed experiences, with some still encountering severe flickering, particularly in environments like tmux. * * 2. **User Frustrations**: * ‚Ä¢ Many commenters criticized the slow resolution of the issue, with some expressing disbelief that it took months to address such a visible problem. * ‚Ä¢ Several users pointed out poor communication from Anthropic, highlighting a lack of updates on GitHub and suggesting that the lack of transparency eroded user trust. * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters speculated that Claude Code's internal development process, potentially involving the use of its own tool, might be hindering progress. * * 3. **Comparisons to Competitors**: * ‚Ä¢ OpenAI's Codex was frequently mentioned as a smoother and more reliable alternative, with its Rust-based implementation seen as a contributing factor. * ‚Ä¢ Other CLI tools like opencode, gemini, and droid were cited as examples of systems that do not suffer from similar issues. * * 4. **Technical Suggestions and Critiques**: * ‚Ä¢ Commenters debated the use of the Ink library for TUI rendering, with some suggesting alternative approaches like ncurses or ratatui. * ‚Ä¢ There were calls to decouple the TUI/UI from Claude Code to allow users to build custom interfaces. * ‚Ä¢ The use of a PTY proxy was criticized for breaking features like Ghostty's native scrollback. * * 5. **Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment was mixed but leaned negative. Many users expressed frustration and disappointment with the slow progress and lingering issues, though some acknowledged the complexity of the problem and appreciated the team's efforts. * ‚Ä¢ A few comments were humorous or sarcastic, highlighting the perceived irony of an advanced AI tool struggling with basic terminal functionality. * * 6. **Suggestions for Improvement**: * ‚Ä¢ Improved communication and transparency from the Claude Code team were repeatedly emphasized as critical for rebuilding trust. * ‚Ä¢ Some users suggested open-sourcing the project to allow the community to contribute fixes, though others expressed skepticism about the quality of the codebase. * * 7. **Unique Insights**: * ‚Ä¢ A commenter humorously suggested that achieving AGI might require Claude Code to fix its own flickering issue. * ‚Ä¢ Another noted the high resource usage of Claude Code, questioning why a TUI tool would consume significant memory. * * 8. **Community Reactions**: * ‚Ä¢ While some users expressed gratitude for the update and improvements, others highlighted that the issue still persisted in their setups, indicating that the solution was not universally effective. * ‚Ä¢ The discussion revealed a strong desire for more robust and stable tools, with many users advocating for a focus on performance and reliability over new features.
----------------------------------------
Electricity use of AI coding agents ‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.simonpcouch.com/blog/2026-01-20-cc-impact/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46695415 ‚Ä¢ Score: 100 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/93a0f874-83c4-49dc-94ba-5b1f371074dc.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/0f1b7270-f76a-48d8-b09d-869c1570fb8e.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ Research shows that for typical users, AI chatbot energy consumption is negligible, with a "median query" using around 0.3 Wh‚Äîequivalent to a rounding error in personal electricity usage. * ‚Ä¢ However, "extreme power users," such as developers using coding agents like Claude Code, consume significantly more energy. A median Claude Code session uses 41 Wh, 138 times more than a typical query, and daily usage can reach 1,300 Wh‚Äîcomparable to running a dishwasher or an extra refrigerator daily. * ‚Ä¢ Detailed analysis of Claude Code sessions reveals that energy consumption scales with token usage, with pessimistic estimates suggesting up to 390 Wh/MTok for input and 1,950 Wh/MTok for output in high-demand scenarios. This highlights the need for efficiency improvements in AI systems for intensive use cases.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Topics and Themes**: * ‚Ä¢ **Cost of AI-Assisted Development**: The discussion begins with a focus on the costs associated with using AI tools for software development, such as the $50 cost cited for a small code change. Commenters debate whether these costs are reasonable, with some noting that these expenses can be misleading due to broader usage of AI tools. * ‚Ä¢ **Anthropic's Pricing Model**: Several commenters criticize the pricing model of Anthropic, particularly the "pay by the token" option, which is deemed inefficient compared to subscription plans. Suggestions are made to optimize usage by adjusting model settings to reduce costs. * ‚Ä¢ **Energy Usage of LLMs**: The conversation also delves into the energy consumption of large language models (LLMs), comparing it to everyday activities like running a dishwasher or refrigerator. Commenters debate whether this comparison is appropriate and discuss the ecological impact of LLM usage. * ‚Ä¢ **Training vs. Inference Costs**: A recurring point of contention is how to account for the energy and financial costs of training LLMs versus inference (usage). Some argue that training costs are fixed and should not be conflated with inference, while others emphasize the ongoing resource demands of training and updating models. * ‚Ä¢ **Environmental Impact and Regulation**: The broader environmental implications of AI energy use are discussed, with some advocating for regulation to internalize externalities, while others argue that these costs are already reflected in pricing. * * 2. **Key Agreements**: * ‚Ä¢ Many commenters agree that Anthropic's "pay by the token" pricing model is inefficient and recommend subscription plans for cost savings. * ‚Ä¢ There is a general consensus that the energy use of LLMs, while significant, is relatively small compared to other global energy demands, such as air travel. * ‚Ä¢ Commenters highlight the importance of optimizing AI settings to reduce costs and energy consumption for simple tasks. * * 3. **Key Disagreements**: * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters debate whether training costs should be included in the per-token cost of inference, with differing views on the economic and ecological implications. * ‚Ä¢ Opinions diverge on the need for regulation, with some advocating for government intervention to address externalities and others arguing that current pricing already accounts for these costs. * * 4. **Unique Insights**: * ‚Ä¢ One commenter draws an analogy between LLM energy usage and human brain efficiency, emphasizing the brain's superior multimodality and energy efficiency compared to AI. * ‚Ä¢ Another commenter notes that training costs, while significant, are minor in the context of global energy consumption, citing the airline industry as a much larger contributor to fossil fuel use. * ‚Ä¢ A service called NeuralWatt is mentioned, which measures and optimizes AI energy usage, highlighting potential solutions for reducing energy impact. * * 5. **Overall Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The sentiment of the discussion is mixed but leans toward constructive criticism. Commenters are generally pragmatic, focusing on cost optimization and efficiency improvements while acknowledging the broader environmental concerns of AI usage.
----------------------------------------
Majority of CEOs report zero payoff from AI splurge ‚Ä¢ Article: https://www.theregister.com/2026/01/20/pwc_ai_ceo_survey/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46696636 ‚Ä¢ Score: 90 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/e565c8de-bb48-4073-97bf-8bfd71fa643f.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/6bcfca94-c074-4cd0-92fd-ae35a26c4694.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ Over 56% of CEOs report seeing no increase in revenue or decrease in costs from AI, despite significant investments, highlighting the early-stage nature of AI adoption. Only 12% reported dual benefits of reduced costs and higher revenue. * ‚Ä¢ PwC emphasizes that isolated AI projects rarely yield measurable value, advocating for enterprise-wide AI deployments aligned with business strategy and supported by strong foundational infrastructure. * ‚Ä¢ Scaling AI remains a challenge, with MIT research showing only 5% of companies successfully implementing AI tools at scale, while geopolitical risks, cyber threats, and uncertainty over AI benefits weigh on CEO confidence.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Cost and Value of AI Tools**: * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters discussed the cost-effectiveness of AI tools, particularly AI coding assistants. Opinions varied on whether these tools justify their expense. * ‚Ä¢ Some, like "techblueberry," questioned whether AI tools provide tangible monetary value, noting the potential for wasted resources without discipline in usage. * ‚Ä¢ Others highlighted the affordability of current AI tools, with "blargey" noting that premium plans for tools like Claude are much less than the hypothetical $10k/head mentioned. * ‚Ä¢ Individual perspectives on spending ranged widely, with "bluecalm" willing to pay $300/month for hobby projects due to productivity benefits, while "thewebguyd" expressed reluctance to spend personal money on such tools. * * 2. **AI's Practical Impact and Adoption**: * ‚Ä¢ There was debate over the actual benefits of AI adoption. A PwC survey was referenced, indicating that 56% of companies saw neither higher revenues nor lower costs from AI, with only 12% experiencing both benefits. * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters, like "jajuuka," argued that adoption and benefits might grow over time, akin to early internet adoption, while others, like "imiric," expressed skepticism about this "snowball effect. * ‚Ä¢ Several noted that the success of AI tools often depends on the organizational culture and effectiveness, with "jbs789" emphasizing that AI doesn't fix underlying corporate dysfunction. * * 3. **Corporate Dysfunction and AI**: * ‚Ä¢ A recurring theme was how AI adoption reveals corporate inefficiencies. Commenters like "verdverm" and "svilen_dobrev" noted parallels to past trends like Agile, where tools exposed existing process issues rather than solving them outright. * ‚Ä¢ Some argued that AI's inability to address these dysfunctions might limit its transformative potential in many companies. * * 4. **Skepticism and Sentiment on AI Hype**: * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters expressed skepticism about the current AI hype, comparing it to past tech bubbles. "xvxvx" predicted a painful burst of the AI bubble, while "imiric" noted concerns about the broader tech market and political climate. * ‚Ä¢ Others, like "Bukhmanizer," suggested that much of the enthusiasm around AI replacing workers is driven by fear or wishful thinking rather than realistic predictions. * * 5. **Diverse Use Cases and Experiences**: * ‚Ä¢ Commenters shared varied experiences with AI tools. Some found them invaluable for specific tasks, such as "thorncorona" revamping a home lab with a $20/month subscription, while others, like "dvfjsdhgfv," found limited utility for complex or nuanced projects. * ‚Ä¢ The sentiment on AI's usefulness was mixed, with some praising its ability to save time on repetitive tasks and others lamenting its limitations and potential to erode personal skills. * * 6. **Broader Implications and Comparisons**: * ‚Ä¢ Comparisons were made to past tech revolutions, such as the personal computer boom of the 1980s. While some, like "labrador," saw parallels, others, like "acdha," argued that AI lacks the immediate, clear wins that PCs offered. * ‚Ä¢ The discussion also touched on AI's role in advertising, with "lp0_on_fire" suggesting that adopting ads is a standard revenue strategy rather than evidence of AI's success. * * **Overall Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The discussion reflected a mix of cautious optimism, skepticism, and critical analysis. While some commenters highlighted the potential and current utility of AI tools, many questioned their long-term value, the sustainability of the hype, and the readiness of organizations to adopt them effectively.
----------------------------------------
Show HN: I built a tool to assist AI agents to know when a PR is good to go ‚Ä¢ Article: https://dsifry.github.io/goodtogo/ ‚Ä¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46656759 ‚Ä¢ Score: 44 ‚Ä¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/19edb3a4-6a3d-4f5c-968d-f57a838c2e2b.mp3 ‚Ä¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen https://audios.aicrafter.info/d7938db5-a225-4181-b3c7-3c3a5cfd1d2f.mp3
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info https://aicrafter.info.
ARTICLE SUMMARY:
* ‚Ä¢ "Good To Go" addresses a critical gap in AI-assisted coding by providing a deterministic way to assess if a pull request (PR) is ready to merge. It eliminates guesswork with clear statuses like READY, ACTION_REQUIRED, or CI_FAILING. * ‚Ä¢ The tool uses advanced analysis across CI status aggregation, intelligent comment classification, and thread resolution tracking, ensuring actionable insights for developers and AI agents. * ‚Ä¢ Designed for seamless AI integration, it offers structured outputs, state persistence, and automation-friendly features, streamlining workflows and reducing inefficiencies in PR management.
DISCUSSION HIGHLIGHTS:
* 1. **Main Discussion Points**: * ‚Ä¢ The discussion centers around a tool that automates parts of the code review and merging process, with a focus on whether AI should handle tasks like merging code autonomously or simply prepare pull requests (PRs) for human review. * ‚Ä¢ Several commenters highlight the potential benefits of AI-driven workflows, such as improving efficiency, ensuring CI (Continuous Integration) checks are passed, and reducing human effort in resolving trivial issues. * ‚Ä¢ Concerns are raised about security vulnerabilities, such as the potential for malicious bug reports or misuse by bad actors if AI systems are integrated into broader development workflows. * ‚Ä¢ Some commenters emphasize the importance of maintaining human oversight, particularly when dealing with ambiguous feedback or critical code review decisions. * * 2. **Agreements and Disagreements**: * ‚Ä¢ There is general agreement that AI tools can be useful for automating repetitive tasks and improving workflow efficiency, but opinions diverge on how far automation should go. Some commenters support full automation if sufficient testing is in place, while others argue that human review remains essential to prevent errors or vulnerabilities. * ‚Ä¢ Disagreements arise over the practicality and reliability of AI-driven tools, with some viewing them as a natural progression in software development and others expressing skepticism about their value compared to existing tools like GitHub status checks and branch protections. * * 3. **Unique Insights**: * ‚Ä¢ One commenter suggests that integrating unresolved comments into CI checks could be an innovative way to ensure code quality before merging, which was described as a valuable idea for AI-driven PRs. * ‚Ä¢ Another highlights the challenges of adapting legacy codebases for AI-driven workflows, noting that significant refactoring and organizational work will be required to achieve consistent results. * ‚Ä¢ A perspective is shared on the trade-off between slower development velocity and improved code quality when using deterministic AI tools to enforce stricter review processes. * * 4. **Sentiment**: * ‚Ä¢ The overall sentiment of the discussion is mixed. While many commenters acknowledge the potential of AI tools to enhance productivity, there is noticeable skepticism about their current limitations, risks, and the need for careful implementation. * ‚Ä¢ Some frustration is evident from those who feel overwhelmed by the increasing reliance on AI in development, while others express enthusiasm for exploring this new field of research and development. * * 5. **Notable Contributions**: * ‚Ä¢ A commenter points out that tools like the one discussed can provide deterministic feedback and enforce specific development processes, which could lead to better outcomes compared to nondeterministic agents. * ‚Ä¢ Another commenter raises the concern that widespread adoption of such tools could be exploited by malicious actors, emphasizing the need for caution and robust security measures. * ‚Ä¢ The idea of using the tool itself as a CI check was praised as a creative and potentially impactful approach to improving AI-driven workflows. * * In summary, the discussion reflects a mix of optimism and caution regarding AI's role in automating software development processes, with thoughtful consideration of both its benefits and risks.
----------------------------------------

item.title: AI Agenda: AI Videos Nearly Indistinguishable From Real Videos, Runway Finds
item.description:
%title%
AI Agenda By Rocket Drew Jan 21, 2026
Hello! Rocket here.Runway today is releasing its latest AI model, Gen-4.5, that can generate videos from an image. The model, from the startup that specializes in image and video-generating models, is impressive but is likely to underscore growing concerns about AI-generated deepfakes.To measure the model‚Äôs performance, Runway asked over 1,000 people to distinguish real videos from similar videos generated by the model. Participants only guessed correctly 57.1% of the time‚Äînot much better than flipping a coin.¬†Runway came up with the test when its own employees started having a hard time telling apart videos based on digital footage from the outputs of the new model, said Chief Technology Officer Anastasis Germanidis. ‚ÄúWe have probably some of the most trained eyes,‚Äù he said, so if Runway‚Äôs employees were struggling with the task, they figured people who don‚Äôt spend their days scrutinizing AI videos would fare even worse.Runway used its new model to generate a video from the starting frame of clips of real subjects, like animals and human faces. The clips came from Filmpac, a provider of video footage and other media. Runway then trimmed the real and AI videos to five seconds and made sure both had the same resolution.Participants in the study had 10 seconds to guess whether a clip was real or AI-generated. The short time window is realistic, simulating how someone might encounter a video on social media.Germanidis himself took a stab at it. The result? ‚ÄúI failed quite a bit,‚Äù he said.¬†In the study, people did a better job on videos that contained human faces and hands, or humans taking actions. For those videos, accuracy ranged from 58% to 65%. It‚Äôs not that the model is worse at generating those videos: Germanidis thinks people are more attuned to videos of people that look ‚Äúuncanny,‚Äù compared to other subjects.Well before Runway‚Äôs latest model, lawmakers and some technologists were worried about the threat from deepfakes, or AI-generated videos and images that pretend to be legitimate. Those concerns intensified this month, after xAI‚Äôs Grok generated images of women and children wearing bikinis or lingerie, prompting bans in multiple countries and an investigation by the California attorney general.To guard against misinformation, people should ‚Äúhave a more critical mindset‚Äù about the content they see online,‚Äù Germanidis said. ‚ÄúFor us, the study is a way to kind of increase the awareness that at this point we‚Äôre crossing the threshold, and it‚Äôs hard to tell apart generated from real videos.‚ÄùRunway includes in the metadata of its videos that they are AI-generated and is also looking into more reliable ways to watermark these videos, so they can be identified as AI-generated, Germanidis said. Congress has proposed legislation to require watermarking of AI-generated content, and some states have passed laws requiring such disclosures. In Germanidis‚Äô view, the technology is too early to codify specific requirements, but he noted that policies dealing with misinformation in general should cover AI-generated videos.In the U.S., the 2024 presidential election came and went without significant disruption from AI-fueled disinformation, but Runway‚Äôs study is just the latest evidence that the quality of AI models has improved a lot over the past two years. With midterm elections coming up in November, our collective ability to sort fact from fiction will be tested again.If you want to prepare in the meantime, anyone is free to try their hand at a Turing test on Runway‚Äôs website, where the company will be launching a version available to the public, along with a leaderboard to track who can most accurately determine what‚Äôs AI-generated and what‚Äôs not.Here‚Äôs what else is going on‚Ä¶People on the MoveAmazon has tapped former Microsoft executive Jigar Thakkar to lead Quick Suite, a collection of enterprise search and agent-building tools it launched in October as part of a broader push to develop compelling AI applications.Greg Yang, a co-founder of xAI said in a post on X that he‚Äôs stepping back into an informal advisory role to go ‚Äúfounder mode‚Äù on his health, following a diagnosis for Lyme disease. ‚ÄúUntil I pushed myself hard building xAI and weakened my immune system, the symptoms weren't noticeable.‚ÄùOverheard‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let your loved ones use ChatGPT,‚Äù Elon Musk posted on X on Tuesday, in reference to a post about ChatGPT users who committed suicide. The post followed another on Monday, in which Musk wrote ‚ÄúOpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT convinced a guy to do a murder-suicide! To be safe, AI must be maximally truthful-seeking and not pander to delusions.‚ÄùIn response, Altman wrote Tuesday that ‚Äúwe need to protect vulnerable users, while also making sure our guardrails still allow all of our users to benefit from our tools.‚Äù He also said that Musk had previously complained about ChatGPT‚Äôs moderation being too restrictive. ‚ÄúApparently more than 50 people have died from crashes related to Autopilot. I only ever rode in a car using it once, some time ago, but my first thought was that it was far from a safe thing for Tesla to have released. I won‚Äôt even start on some of the Grok decisions,‚Äù Altman wrote.Meanwhile, at Davos, Google DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis said he would be open to a d√©tente in the AI race. In an interview with Bloomberg, Hassabis said would likely support a pause on AI development if every AI company agreed to it. He said he would like to see companies collaborate on AI development as they approach the creation of human-level AI, but unfortunately ‚Äúinternational cooperation‚Äôs a little bit tricky at the moment.‚Äù Presumably, such a pause would also ease tensions between the CEOs of those companies on social media!Policy WatchAnthropic has hired three new lobbying firms since the beginning of December, Politico reported, citing recent disclosures. The firms are Thorn Run Partners, Kountoupes Denham Carr & Reid and Avenue Solutions.Anthropic spent over $1 million in lobbying expenditures in the third quarter last year, Politico reported. That‚Äôs more than OpenAI spent in that period, but less than Meta or Amazon.Deals and DebutsSee The Information‚Äôs Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.Zipline, a drone delivery startup, raised over $600 million at a $7.6 billion valuation, in a funding round from investors including Valor Equity Partners, Tiger Global, Fidelity Management and Research Company and Baillie Gifford.Humans&, which is developing ‚Äúhuman-centric‚Äù AI tools, raised $480 million at $4.48 billion valuation in a seed funding round led by SV Angel and co-founder Georges Harik, with participation from Nvidia, Jeff Bezos, GV, Emerson Collective, Forerunner, S32, DCVC, Human Capital, Felicis and CRV.Baseten, which helps run AI models for companies including Cursor and Notion, raised $300 million at a $5 billion valuation in a funding round led by IVP and CapitalG, with participation from Nvidia, which invested $150 million, the Wall Street Journal reported.OpenEvidence, which provides a ‚ÄúChatGPT for doctors,‚Äù raised $250 million in funding at a $12 billion valuation led by¬†Thrive Capital and DST Global. The Information first broke the round here.Emergent, which provides AI for developing apps, raised $70 million in a Series B funding round at a $300 million valuation led by Khosla Ventures and SoftBank.Applied Compute, which uses reinforcement learning to customize AI models, is in talks to raise up to $70 million at a $1.3 billion valuation, The Information reported. Kleiner Perkins is in talks to lead the round.Datarails, which offers AI-powered FP&A software, raised $70 million in Series C funding led by One Peak.Ivo, which uses AI to help lawyers review contracts, raised $55 million in a Series B funding round led by Blackbird.Unbox Robotics, which develops warehouse robots, raised $28 million in a Series B funding round led by Icici Venture and Restart Labs.OpenAI is asking a small group of advertisers for spending commitments of less than $1 million each over a several week trial period, as the company tests new ads within its ChatGPT chatbot, The Information reported.OpenAI also began adding age verification to ChatGPT. If OpenAI estimates that a user is under 18, ChatGPT adds additional restrictions, including on violence and romantic roleplay.ServiceNow has signed a multi-year deal to pay for OpenAI‚Äôs artificial intelligence models in its business software, the two companies said on Tuesday. Under the agreement, OpenAI will now be the ‚Äúpreferred‚Äù AI model provider in ServiceNow‚Äôs software. In the past, ServiceNow let customers choose between AI models from OpenAI or other providers including Google and Anthropic.Amazon is open to working with other companies to run their AI shopping assistants on its site, where it already offers its own shopping chatbot, CEO Andy Jassy said in an interview with The Information‚Äôs Jessica Lessin at the World Economic Forum in Davos.X released the algorithm it uses to recommend posts in users‚Äô For You feeds. The algorithm ranks posts using ‚Äúa Grok-based transformer model that predicts engagement probabilities for each post.‚Äù72% of ChatGPT subscribers have set ChatGPT to their browser homepage, replacing traditional search engines, according to a survey conducted by Bango, a subscription bundling company.Adobe released new AI features in Acrobat, such as the ability to generate podcast summaries based on files, create presentations and edit files using prompts.
A message from ServiceNow
Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.
Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNow¬Æ works the way people do. It brings text, voice, images, and agents into a single, seamless interface where AI is the new UI. Learn more
New From Our Reporters
ExclusiveOpenAI Lines Up Advertisers, Reveals Key Details Ahead of Ads Launch By Catherine Perloff and Sri Muppidi
ExclusiveApplied Compute, Founded by Ex-OpenAI Researchers, in Talks for $1.3 Billion Valuation By Stephanie Palazzolo and Valida Pau
ExclusiveTikTok Plans Big Shopping Push By Jing Yang and Juro Osawa
Recommended Newsletter
Every weekday, The Briefing helps executives get smarter about the latest in tech, media and finance.¬†Subscribe for free now.
What We‚Äôre Reading
UK exposed to ‚Äòserious harm‚Äô by failure to tackle AI risks, MPs warn
Anthropic CEO Says AI Chip Sales to China Like Selling Nukes to North Korea
Ukraine to share wartime combat data with allies to help train AI
Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! I‚Äôd love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign up¬†here.
